[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Smith. I’m Alex, I'm one of the nurses from the City Hospital where you're being transferred to. I’ll get handover from my colleague now, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is bed 12, John Smith, 78 years old, under Dr. Patel.
He was admitted two days ago following a fall at home, resulting in a displaced fracture of the left femur. He’s being transferred for surgical fixation.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has a history of Type 2 Diabetes and mild dementia. He’s usually oriented to person and place but can become confused in unfamiliar environments. Observations have been stable, and pain is managed with regular paracetamol.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:
Hi Mr. Smith, can you tell us your full name to confirm your ID?
[PATIENT]: John Smith.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: And your date of birth?.
[PATIENT]: first of June 1948 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I'll check you ID number on your wristband, it's 479023, which is correct. Are you having any discomfort right now?
[PATIENT]: Just a bit of pain in my leg, but it’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No interventions overnight. Vital signs remained within normal limits: BP: 132/78, HR:88, RR:18, Temp: 36.8. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any allergies we should know about? I’ll double-check your chart as well.
[PATIENT]: Please check the chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Bloods from yesterday show: Hb:125, CRP:12, HbA1c:7.4 from last month. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s currently NBM for surgery. IV fluids are running at maintenance rate.
No anticoagulants. Pressure area care in place. Nil weight-bearing.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So, the plan is to continue monitoring and prepare for surgical fixation. There are no outstanding tasks at this stage.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Everything is up to date.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Smith, is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:
Okay, I’ll be back shortly to check on you again.

example.text:
[PHARMACIST]: Hi Dr. Lee, I wanted to speak with you about Mr. James Carter, who’s being discharged today. He’s being started on warfarin for atrial fibrillation post-op, and I’m organising his discharge medications and follow-up.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. What’s the current plan?
[PHARMACIST]: He’s had two doses of warfarin so far—5 mg on Day 1 and 3 mg yesterday. His INR this morning was 1.6, so still subtherapeutic. I’ve charted 3 mg again today, and we’ll need to arrange ongoing INR monitoring through his GP or local pathology service.
[DOCTOR]: Okay. Has the GP been contacted?
[PHARMACIST]: Not yet. I was going to ask if you’d like to send a discharge summary with a note to the GP to monitor INR every 2–3 days initially, and adjust dosing as needed. I’ll also include a warfarin education leaflet and a yellow book for tracking.
[DOCTOR]: Yes, please include that in the discharge paperwork. Has he been counselled?
[PHARMACIST]: Yes, I’ve spoken with him about, Dietary interactions (especially vitamin K), Bleeding risks, Signs to report (e.g. bruising, blood in urine/stool), Avoiding NSAIDs and alcohol, He’s aware and has agreed to follow up with his GP.
[DOCTOR]: Great. Any other meds to note?
[PHARMACIST]: He’s also on, Metoprolol 25 mg BD, Atorvastatin 40 mg nocte, Paracetamol PRN, No known drug allergies.
[DOCTOR]: Perfect. I’ll finalise the discharge summary and include the INR plan. Thanks for organising everything.
[PHARMACIST]: No problem. I’ll send the warfarin pack with him and notify the GP clinic once he’s discharged.

[WARD NURSE 1]: Hey, just handing over James Taylor, 42 years old, admitted yesterday with severe tonsillitis. He’s heading to theatre later this morning for a tonsillectomy.
[WARD NURSE 2]: Okay, thanks. What’s his current status?
[WARD NURSE 1]: He’s afebrile now, vitals are stable — RR 16, SpO? 98% on room air, HR 82. Still has significant throat pain and is nil by mouth in preparation for surgery. ENT reviewed him this morning and confirmed he’s on the list.
[WARD NURSE 2]: Got it. Any IV access?
[WARD NURSE 1]: Yes, 20G in the right forearm — patent and secure. He’s had IV fluids and antibiotics this morning. No known drug allergies.
[WARD NURSE 2]: Any behavioural or cognitive concerns?
[WARD NURSE 1]: No concerns. He’s alert and cooperative, just a bit anxious about the procedure, which is understandable.
[WARD NURSE 2]: Has the pre-op checklist been done?
[WARD NURSE 1]: Yep — checklist complete, consent signed, anaesthetics team has reviewed. Theatre is booked for 11:30 AM. Just keep an eye out for any changes and let the team know if there’s a delay.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 8, Jake Morrison, 23 years old. He’s Day 1 post-VATS for a left-sided pneumothorax following a football injury on Saturday. He’s just come back from theatre this morning.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How’s he doing?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s stable post-op. Vitals are within normal limits. He’s alert and orientated, but still a bit groggy from anaesthetic.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any drains or lines?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, he has: One chest drain on the left side, currently on suction, IV cannula in the right forearm, PCA in place – fentanyl-based, set up and functioning
He’s been shown how to use the PCA but may need reinforcement. He’s hesitant and unsure about pressing the button.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll go over it with him again.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pain score is around 4/10 at rest, 6/10 on movement. He’s tolerating oral fluids and has had a light meal. No nausea or vomiting.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other concerns?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s understandably anxious about the chest drain and movement. He’s due for a physio review later today to start gentle breathing exercises and mobilisation.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any allergies or medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No known drug allergies. Regular meds include paracetamol and ibuprofen pre-op. Post-op: Fentanyl PCA, Paracetamol 1g QID, Ondansetron PRN, Cephazolin IV (prophylactic).
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll check the drain output and reinforce PCA use.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything changes. He’s currently resting in bed.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Lien Tran, 82 years old, here for a renal ultrasound to investigate reduced kidney function. She’s from a Vietnamese-speaking background and does not speak English. She also has significant vision impairment and is deaf.
[RADIOGRAPHER]: Thanks. How does she communicate?
[NURSE]: She uses Vietnamese sign language and gestures. Her daughter is on the way and usually helps interpret. In the meantime, we’ve requested a Vietnamese interpreter, but they haven’t arrived yet. I’ve written out some basic instructions in large print Vietnamese, but she may still need assistance understanding the procedure.
[RADIOGRAPHER]: Is she medically stable?
[NURSE]: Yes, vitals are stable. She’s a bit anxious due to the unfamiliar environment and communication barriers, so a calm approach will help.
[RADIOGRAPHER]: Any mobility issues?
[NURSE]: She’s ambulant with assistance. She uses a walking frame and needs help getting on and off the bed.
[RADIOGRAPHER]: Any allergies or medications?
[NURSE]: No known drug allergies. She’s on Amlodipine 5 mg daily, Furosemide 40 mg daily, Calcium carbonates she’s Nil by mouth for the scan and has had fluids withheld this morning.
[RADIOGRAPHER]: I’ll wait for the interpreter or her daughter before starting. I’ll keep her comfortable in the meantime.
[NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if you need anything else.

example.text:
[ED_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Lien Tran, 82 years old, transferring to your ward for further investigation of renal impairment. She’s here for a renal ultrasound to help diagnose the issue.
[WARD_NURSE]: Thanks. Can you tell me a bit about her background?
[ED_NURSE]: Sure. She’s from a Vietnamese-speaking background, does not speak English, and is deaf. She also has significant vision impairment. Communication is a challenge—she uses Vietnamese sign language and gestures, but we’ve requested a Vietnamese interpreter. Her daughter is on the way and usually helps with communication.
[WARD_NURSE]: How is she medically?
[ED_NURSE]: Her Vitals are stable, She’s alert but anxious due to the unfamiliar environment and communication barriers.
[WARD_NURSE]: Any mobility concerns?
[ED_NURSE]: She’s ambulant with assistance and uses a walking frame. Needs help with transfers and getting on/off the bed.
[WARD_NURSE]: Any medications or allergies?
[ED_NURSE]: No known drug allergies. She’s on, Amlodipine 5 mg daily, Furosemide 40 mg daily, Calcium carbonate, she’s nil by mouth for the scan and fluids have been withheld this morning.
[WARD_NURSE]:  Anything else I should be aware of?
[ED_NURSE]: Just be mindful of her communication needs and vision impairment. I’ve left a large print Vietnamese instruction sheet at the bedside, but she may still need support. Her daughter should arrive shortly and can assist.
[WARD_NURSE]: I’ll get her settled and follow up with the interpreter service.
[ED_NURSE]: Let me know if anything changes.

example.text:
[ED_NURSE]:
Hi, thanks for coming. I’m handing over Mr. Leo Martinez, 56 years old, admitted through ED earlier today with chest pain and a history of Type 2 diabetes. He also consumed a large amount of alcohol last night and presented confused and groggy.
[WARD_NURSE]: What’s his current status?
[ED_NURSE]: He’s still a bit drowsy, but responsive. Chest pain has eased slightly with initial treatment. Vitals are stable BP: 108/72, HR: 96 bpm, RR: 20, SpO?: 95% on room air, Temp: 36.7°C, BGL: 14.2 mmol/L on arrival, now 11.6 mmol/L
[DOCTOR]: We’re admitting him for cardiac monitoring and further investigation. ECG showed non-specific changes, and we’re awaiting troponin results. He’s also at risk of alcohol withdrawal, so we’ve started a CIWA protocol and charted thiamine and diazepam PRN.
[WARD_NURSE]: Any IV access?
[ED_NURSE]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in the left forearm, patent and flushed. Fluids are running at maintenance rate.
[WARD_NURSE]: Any allergies or regular meds?
[ED_NURSE]: No known drug allergies. Regular meds include, Metformin 500 mg BD, Atorvastatin 20 mg nocte, PRN insulin sliding scale (not charted today due to alcohol intake)
[DOCTOR]: We’ll need to involve the Drug and Alcohol Team tomorrow for support. He’s also been referred to Cardiology for review.
[WARD_NURSE]: Is he safe to mobilise?
[ED_NURSE]:
Not really sure we haven't tried to get him up.
[PATIENT]: Where am I now?
[WARD_NURSE]: Hi Mr. Martinez, you’re being moved to the ward now so we can keep a close eye on your heart and help you feel better. I’ll be looking after you.
[PATIENT]: Okay… my chest still feels tight.
[DOCTOR]: We’ll keep monitoring that. Let us know if it gets worse.
[WARD_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll get him settled and continue obs and withdrawal monitoring.
[ED_NURSE]: Perfect. All documentation is up to date. Let me know if you need anything

pred_spans.label: SITUATION
pred_spans.quote: I’m handing over Mr. Leo Martinez, 56 years old, admitted through ED earlier today with chest pain and a history of Type 2 diabetes. He also consumed a large amount of alcohol last night and presented confused and groggy.

pred_spans.label: ASSESSMENT

[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Daniel Hayes, 67 years old, just returned from the cath lab following a coronary angiogram. He’s being transferred back to CCU for ongoing monitoring.
[CCU_NURSE]: Thanks. How did the procedure go?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Procedure was uneventful. No stents placed today—angiogram was diagnostic only. He still has the femoral sheath in situ, and it needs to be transduced for haemodynamic monitoring. His heart rate is low, sitting around 48 bpm, so we’re keeping a close eye on it.
[CCU_NURSE]: Okay. What are his current vitals?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: BP: 110/68, HR: 48 bpm, sinus bradycardia, RR: 16, SpO?: 97% on room air, Temp: 36.6°C, He’s alert and orientated, but a bit tired post-procedure.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any lines or medications?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Yes, a Femoral sheath – still in place, not yet transduced, IV cannula in left forearm, No IV infusions running currently, no sedation required post-procedure and probably has some usual meds
[CCU_NURSE]: Any pain or bleeding?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: No active bleeding. Puncture site is clean and dressed. No complaints of pain. He’s on bed rest, and we’ve reinforced strict leg immobilisation.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any medications charted?
[CCU_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll get the sheath transduced and continue monitoring his HR closely.
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything changes. All documentation is up to date.

example.text:
[DOCTOR]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Amir Rahman, 63 years old, admitted yesterday with what looks like a large anterior MI — the ECG was fairly convincing. He’s currently in ICU. They started an intra‑aortic balloon pump yesterday evening, mainly as a bridge to CABG, which is tentatively booked for two days from now, but that might shift depending on his stability.
[ICU_NURSE]: Thanks. Can you give me a quick overview?
[DOCTOR]: Sure. He’s still a bit haemodynamically shaky post‑MI, with ongoing low cardiac output. The IABP went in this morning via the femoral artery — I believe the cardiology registrar did it. It’s set to 1:1 augmentation. So far, he seems to be responding — BP’s come up a bit, and lactates look like they’re trending down, though the last result isn’t in yet.
[ICU_NURSE]: Any other lines or support?
[DOCTOR]: Right, he’s got an arterial line in the right radial for continuous BP monitoring, a central line in the right internal jugular, and an IDC in situ. I think he’s also still connected to telemetry, but I’ll need to double‑check if that’s linked to the central monitoring unit. He’s on low‑dose noradrenaline, sitting around 2 micrograms a minute, but that’s fluctuated a little. IV heparin is running for balloon pump patency — pharmacy flagged a possible review of APTT later today.
[ICU_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[DOCTOR]: Yes, he’s from a non‑English speaking background — Arabic’s his first language. He understands basic English, but it’s hit‑and‑miss for more complex instructions. Somebody requested an interpreter for the family conference, but I’m not sure if it’s been booked yet. His son’s bilingual and has been helping, though he might not be around later tonight.
[ICU_NURSE]: Any pain or sedation?
[DOCTOR]: He’s alert and orientated. No sedation required at this stage. Pain’s reasonably controlled with paracetamol and occasional oxycodone — he said it’s “okay,” but sounded a bit unsure. He’s anxious — understandably — so maybe consider whether some short‑acting anxiolytic’s needed if he escalates later.
[ICU_NURSE]: Any allergies or medications?
[DOCTOR]: No known drug allergies as far as documented. Meds include aspirin 100 mg daily, atorvastatin 80 mg nocte, the IV heparin infusion, noradrenaline, and the PRNs — paracetamol and oxycodone. I’ll have to check if his beta blocker’s been restarted post‑MI; cardiology had mentioned it but I didn’t see an order yet.
[ICU_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll keep monitoring IABP function and haemodynamics closely.
[DOCTOR]: Perfect. Let me know if there’s any change in rhythm, perfusion, or balloon timing. I think the surgical team’s planning to review tomorrow morning, but if anything shifts overnight — especially haemodynamics or rhythm — just flag them or cardiac reg overnight.

example.text:
[CATHLABNURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Fatima El-Sayed, 61 years old, just returned from the cath lab following an angiogram and stent placement for an anterior STEMI. She’s being transferred back to CCU for ongoing monitoring and support.
[CCU_NURSE]: Can you give me a summary?
[CATHLABNURSE]: Sure. She had two stents placed in the LAD. The myocardium is stunned, and she’s currently supported with an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP). It’s set to 1:1 augmentation, and she’s tolerating it well so far. She’s haemodynamically stable but requires close monitoring.
[CCU_NURSE]:
Vitals?
[CATHLABNURSE]: BP: 98/60, HR: 52 bpm – sinus bradycardia, RR: 18, SpO?: 96% on room air, Temp: 36.8°C. She’s alert but fatigued. No chest pain currently.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any lines or attachments?
[CATHLABNURSE]: she has a IABP via right femoral artery, an Arterial line in left radial a CVL in right internal jugular, an IDC in place draining over 30mls an hour. And Telemetry monitoring. She’s on IV heparin infusion for IABP patency and low-dose noradrenaline at 2 mcg/min.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any investigations pending?
[CATHLABNURSE]: Yes, she’s booked for a chest X-ray to confirm IABP positioning and a transthoracic echocardiogram to assess myocardial function. Cardiology team will review later today.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[CATHLABNURSE]: Yes, she’s from a non-English speaking background—Arabic is her first language. She understands basic English but struggles with medical terms. Her daughter is bilingual and has been helping. Interpreter has been requested for ward rounds.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any allergies or medications?
[CATHLABNURSE]:
No known drug allergies. 
[CCU_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll transduce the IABP and continue monitoring closely.
[CATHLABNURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything changes. All documentation is up to date.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 3, Ms. Elena Petrova, 47 years old. She’s been admitted for major depressive disorder and has been on amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant, for the past two weeks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. What’s happening currently?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s developed an oculogyric crisis—her eyes are rolling upward involuntarily, and she’s visibly distressed. It started about an hour ago. She’s aware of it and frightened, but still orientated and able to speak.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Has medical been notified?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, the on-call doctor has reviewed her. They suspect it’s a dystonic reaction to the tricyclics. IM benztropine 2 mg has been charted and given about 20 minutes ago. We’re monitoring for response.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other symptoms?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No limb dystonia or airway involvement. Her Vitals are stable, She’s anxious but cooperative.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she’s from a non-English speaking background—Russian is her first language. She understands basic English but struggles with medical terms. Interpreter has been requested for tomorrow’s review. Her daughter is bilingual and has been helping.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on: Amitriptyline 75 mg nocte, Diazepam 5 mg PRN, Paracetamol PRN. There is No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll continue monitoring her response to benztropine and keep her calm.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if the symptoms persist or worsen. All documentation is up to date.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Patel, I need to escalate a concern about Mr. Thomas Nguyen, 74 years old, currently in bed 5 on the urology ward. He’s been deteriorating clinically — I’m not exactly sure what’s triggering it, but I think he needs a medical review soon, possibly urgently.
[DOCTOR]: Okay, what’s going on?
[NURSE]: He was admitted yesterday with acute urinary retention and a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia. A catheter was inserted last night, but over the last few hours he seems to have become more lethargic, tachycardic, and hypotensive. His urine output’s dropped quite a bit — not sure if the catheter’s blocked or if he’s just shutting down.
[DOCTOR]: What are his current vitals?
[NURSE]: BP’s sitting around 88/54, HR about 112, RR 22, SpO₂ 96% on room air, temp 37.9°C. He’s only passed about 40 mL in the last three hours, give or take. His Q‑ADDS is around 7, though I’ll double‑check — it might be 8 depending on the scoring for output.
[DOCTOR]: Any pain or other symptoms?
[NURSE]: He’s got some lower abdominal discomfort — says it’s “tight” more than painful — and a low‑grade fever. He’s a bit confused, which the team on shift earlier didn’t mention, so that’s new. No vomiting that I’ve seen, but he’s refusing fluids and looks a little clammy.
[DOCTOR]: Any recent bloods?
[NURSE]: Yes, this morning’s labs: white cell 14.6, CRP 98, creatinine 168 from 102 yesterday, eGFR down to 44 — sorry, I think it’s 44, not 4, but I can confirm. Looks like he might be heading into an acute kidney injury, possibly secondary to infection, obstruction, or both. Micro hasn’t come back yet, but urine looked cloudy.
[DOCTOR]: Okay, thanks. I’ll come and review him now — give me about ten minutes. We may need imaging and probably to escalate to the surgical team if obstruction’s worsening. I’ll decide once I’ve seen him.
[NURSE]: Alright, I’ll keep an eye on him for now and prepare in case you want to transfer or escalate further.

[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Good morning, Ms. Lopez. I’m Dr. Chen from City Surgical Unit. I’ll get handover from my colleague now, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: This is bed 5, Maria Lopez, 46 years old, under Dr. Singh.
She was admitted yesterday with acute right upper quadrant pain and nausea. An Ultrasound confirmed multiple gallstones with signs of cholecystitis. She’s being transferred for laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: She’s hemodynamically stable. No signs of biliary obstruction. Her pain is controlled with regular analgesia. There have been no changes in her condition overnight. 
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Hi Ms. Lopez, can you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Maria Lopez.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Thank you. I’ll also check your wristband. That matches.
Are you experiencing any pain or discomfort right now?
[PATIENT]: Just a little soreness, but it’s better than yesterday.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: Vital signs this morning is BP: 124/76, HR: 82 bpm, RR: 16, Temp: 37.2
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Any allergies?
[PATIENT]: None that I know of.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: I’ll confirm that in the chart.
What’s her current medication chart?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]:
She’s currently receiving: IV ceftriaxone 1g daily for suspected cholecystitis, IV metronidazole 500mg TDS, Paracetamol 1g QID orally, Ondansetron 4mg IV PRN for nausea, IV fluids: Normal saline at 100 mL/hr and has been NBM since admission
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Any relevant past medical history?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: Yes: Hypertension (on amlodipine 5mg daily), No diabetes, No previous surgeries, No known liver disease
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: So, the plan is transfer her for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. No outstanding investigations?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]:  Bloods from yesterday: WCC: 11.2, CRP: 45, LFTs: mildly elevated ALT 68, ALP 110, bilirubin is normal, Renal function is normal, her Electrolytes are within range.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]:  Ms. Lopez, is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thank you.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Alright, I’ll see you again shortly once you’re settled in.

[RECOVERY_NURSE]:
Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Thomas Nguyen, 74 years old, transferring to your ward post-procedure. He had a urethral dilation and bladder washout under general anaesthetic due to acute urinary retention and suspected obstructive uropathy.
[WARD_NURSE]: Thanks. How did the procedure go?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: It went smoothly. No complications in theatre. He’s now stable but needs close monitoring due to recent deterioration pre-op—he was hypotensive and oliguric. He’s now passing urine via IDC, and output is improving.
[WARD_NURSE]: Vitals?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: BP: 112/70, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 18, SpO?: 97% on room air, Temp: 37.4°C, Urine output: 120 mL in the last hour
[WARD_NURSE]: Any lines or attachments?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Yes: he has an IDC draining with clear urine, an IV cannula in left forearm, there are No infusions running currently and Oxygen via nasal prongs earlier, now weaned off
[WARD_NURSE]: Any medications charted?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: He’s on: Paracetamol 1g QID, Gentamicin IV stat dose given in theatre, PRN oxycodone and IV fluids were running intra-op, now ceased.
[WARD_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Yes, he’s from a Vietnamese-speaking background and has limited English. Interpreter has been requested for ward rounds. His son is bilingual and will be visiting later today.
[WARD_NURSE]: Thanks. Any outstanding tasks?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: He’s due for post-op obs in 30 minutes, and the IDC needs to be monitored closely. Urology team will review later today. He’s alert but tired.
[WARD_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll get him settled and continue monitoring.
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Great. Let me know if anything changes. All documentation is up to date.

[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Sure. He was admitted with acute urinary retention and a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia. He had some clinical deterioration pre-op—low BP, reduced urine output, and confusion—but he’s responded well to treatment. He’s now passing urine via IDC, and output is improving.

example.text:
[DIETITIAN]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Robert King, 58 years old, currently Day 3 post-abdominal surgery. He’s receiving Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) via a central line due to nil oral intake and delayed return of gut function.
[NURSE]: Thanks. What’s the current TPN plan?
[DIETITIAN]: He’s on a standard TPN formulation with electrolytes, glucose, amino acids, and lipids. It’s running over 24 hours via central line, and we’re monitoring daily bloods—including U&Es, LFTs, glucose, and triglycerides. His fluid balance and weight should be tracked daily.
[NURSE]: Any specific concerns?
[DIETITIAN]: Yes, he’s at risk of refeeding syndrome, so we’ve started thiamine supplementation and are watching his phosphate and magnesium levels closely. So far, electrolytes are stable.
[NURSE]: Is he tolerating the TPN well?
[DIETITIAN]: Yes, no signs of intolerance. No nausea or vomiting. He’s alert and understands the plan. We’ve discussed the importance of not disconnecting the line and keeping the TPN pump running continuously.
[NURSE]: (to patient) Hi Mr. King, I’ll be looking after you today. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: A bit tired, but okay. I’m just hoping I can eat again soon.
[DIETITIAN]: We’re aiming to reassess gut function in the next 48 hours. Once bowel sounds return and surgical team clears it, we’ll start clear fluids, then build up gradually.
[NURSE]: I’ll monitor his obs, fluid balance, and bloods. Anything else?
[DIETITIAN]: Just make sure the TPN line stays dedicated—no meds or flushes through it. And please notify me if there are any signs of infection, line issues, or abnormal blood results.
[NURSE]: Will do. Thanks for the handover.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi, thanks for coming. I wanted to hand over Mrs. Joan Wallace, 69 years old, currently Day 5 post-abdominal surgery for bowel obstruction. She’s still nil by mouth, and the surgical team has recommended a PEG insertion for long-term nutrition support.
[DIETITIAN]: Thanks. Has she been receiving any nutrition support so far?
[NURSE]: Yes, she’s been on IV fluids only. No TPN was started due to concerns about central access and infection risk. She’s starting to show signs of nutritional depletion—fatigue, muscle wasting, and low energy.
[DIETITIAN]: Has the PEG been scheduled?
[NURSE]: Not yet. Gastroenterology has been consulted and will assess her today. Once inserted, she’ll need a feeding plan—likely starting with low-volume, isotonic formula, then gradually increasing.
[DIETITIAN]: Any relevant medical history?
[NURSE]: Yes she has Type 2 diabetes, Hypertension, History of diverticulitis and
No known drug allergies.
[DIETITIAN]: How is she tolerating nil by mouth?
[NURSE]: She’s coping but frustrated. She’s alert and understands the need for PEG feeding. I’ve explained the basics, but she’d benefit from a more detailed discussion with you.
[DIETITIAN]: Hi Mrs. Wallace, I’m the dietitian. I’ll be helping with your nutrition once the feeding tube is in place. We’ll start slowly and make sure you’re comfortable.
[PATIENT]: Thank you. I just want to feel stronger again.
[DIETITIAN]: We’ll work on that together.
[NURSE]: She’s due for bloods tomorrow—please check electrolytes, glucose, and nutritional markers. Let me know if you need anything else.
[DIETITIAN]: Will do. I’ll draft a feeding plan and follow up after the PEG is inserted.

[NURSE]: She’s become increasingly hypotensive and tachycardic, and her respiratory rate is elevated. She’s also confused, which is new. Her urine output has dropped, and she’s looking pale and clammy.
[DOCTOR]: Do you have her latest vitals?
[NURSE]: Yes: BP: 86/52, HR: 118 bpm, RR: 26, SpO?: 94% on 4L nasal prongs, Temp: 38.2°C, Urine output: 30 mL over the last 3 hours and Q-ADDS score: 8

She’s likely heading into sepsis or acute kidney injury.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Patel, thanks for coming. I’d like you to review Ms. Evelyn Grant in bed 9. She’s a 68-year-old admitted with a urinary tract infection, now deteriorating—likely urosepsis.
[DOCTOR]: What’s happening?
[NURSE]: Over the past few hours, she’s become increasingly tachycardic and febrile. Her Q-ADDS score is 6, which triggered escalation. She’s also more confused than her baseline—normally oriented but now disoriented to time and place.
[DOCTOR]: Can you give me her latest observations?
[NURSE]: BP: 98/62, HR: 112 bpm, RR: 22, Temp: 38.6°C, SpO?: 95% on room air, Conscious state: Alert but confused, Q-ADDS score: 6 (HR + Temp + RR + confusion)
[DOCTOR]: Has she had any recent bloods or cultures?
[NURSE]: Yes. Bloods were taken this morning: WCC: 14.2, CRP: 98, Creatinine: 102 (baseline ~85) Urine sample: Sent, we are waiting results Lactate: Not yet done—would you like it ordered?
[DOCTOR]: Any IV access?
[NURSE]: No current vascular access. She had a cannula yesterday, but it was removed due to tissuing. I can insert a new one now.
[DOCTOR]: What’s her fluid balance?
[NURSE]: Input (last 24h): ~1200 mL (oral + IV), Output: ~600 mL urine, no vomiting or diarrhoea, Net balance: +600 mL, Urine output: Reduced over last 6 hours—only 100 mL
[DOCTOR]: Allergy status?
[NURSE]: Documented penicillin allergy—rash and swelling previously.
[DOCTOR]: Current medications?
[NURSE]: Paracetamol 1g QID, IV fluids: Normal saline at 100 mL/hr, No antibiotics yet—awaiting review due to allergy
[DOCTOR]: Okay. I’ll assess her now. Let’s insert a cannula, take a lactate, and start IV ceftriaxone and gentamicin. We’ll monitor closely and consider AMU transfer if she worsens.
[NURSE]: I’ll insert the cannula, draw the lactate, and prep the antibiotics. I’ll also notify AMU if her Q-ADDS increases or confusion worsens.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I just wanted to hand over Mr. Alan Hughes in bed 12. He’s a 74-year-old gentleman with metastatic pancreatic cancer. He’s been transitioned to comfort care and is now actively dying. Based on his current condition, we expect he may only have a few hours left.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. Can you tell me how he’s been over the last shift?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s been mostly unconscious, with shallow breathing and mottled extremities. Respiratory rate is around 8–10, irregular. He hasn’t responded to verbal stimuli since early this morning. His family has been at the bedside and are aware of the situation.
[Incoming Nurse]: Is he comfortable?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, we’ve been managing symptoms proactively. He’s on a subcutaneous syringe driver with: Morphine 10 mg over 24 hours for pain and dyspnoea, Midazolam 10 mg over 24 hours for agitation, Hyoscine butyl bromide 20 mg over 24 hours for secretions. No breakthrough doses needed in the last 6 hours. Mouth care has been done regularly, and pressure areas are being monitored.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any recent changes?
[Outgoing Nurse]: His urine output has ceased, and he hasn’t had any oral intake since yesterday. Skin is cool and cyanosed. We’ve updated the family and offered support. They’re aware of the expected timeframe and have requested privacy.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any escalation plans?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No further interventions planned. ARP is in place. The focus is on comfort and dignity. Please continue regular checks, offer support to the family, and notify the team if any distressing symptoms arise.
[Incoming Nurse]: I’ll keep a close eye and ensure everything remains peaceful.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Lee, I need you to review Ms. Margaret Doyle in bed 7. She’s an 82-year-old patient who had an unwitnessed fall in her room about 45 minutes ago. She hit her head on the bedside cabinet and has a visible occipital hematoma.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. What’s her current condition?
[NURSE]: She’s alert but drowsy. Her GCS is 14—she opens eyes to voice, is confused, and obeys commands. She’s complaining of a headache and mild nausea. No vomiting so far.
[DOCTOR]: Any neuro obs or vitals?
[NURSE]: Yes, we’ve started ½-hourly neuro obs. Her latest set: GCS: 14 ,BP: 132/78, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 18, Temp: 36.8°C, SpO?: 97% on room air, Q-ADDS score: 4 (GCS + nausea + age)
[DOCTOR]: Any bloods done?
[NURSE]: Yes, we drew bloods post-fall. FBC shows: Hb: 122, WCC: 8.6, Platelets: 210, INR: 1.1 Creatinine: 75, She’s not on anticoagulants.
[DOCTOR]: Any other injuries?
[NURSE]: No other obvious trauma. No limb pain or deformity. She mobilised with assistance post-fall but was unsteady.
[DOCTOR]: Okay. We’ll need a CT head to rule out intracranial bleeding. Can you keep neuro obs going and notify me of any GCS drop or vomiting?
[NURSE]: I’ll book the CT and continue neuro obs. I’ll escalate if her Q-ADDS increases or if she becomes more confused

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Nguyen, I need you to review Ms. Lara Bennett in bed 5. She’s a 56-year-old patient with a known history of epilepsy. She had a tonic-clonic seizure about 20 minutes ago on the ward. It lasted approximately 90 seconds and she’s now post-ictal—drowsy but rousable.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. Is she stable now?
[NURSE]:Yes, she’s breathing spontaneously and maintaining her airway. No signs of trauma or tongue injury. She’s currently on 4-hourly neuro obs. Her latest vitals are:BP: 138/84, HR: 92 bpm, RR: 16, Temp: 36.9°C, SpO?: 98% on room air, GCS: 13,Q-ADDS score: 4 (GCS + seizure)
[DOCTOR]: Any IV access?
[NURSE]: Yes, she has a patent IV cannula in her left forearm. No IV fluids running currently—she’s tolerating oral intake. No signs of dehydration.
[DOCTOR]: Any allergies?
[NURSE]: Yes, she has a documented allergy to phenytoin—rash and dizziness previously.
[DOCTOR]: Is she catheterised?
[NURSE]: Yes, she has an indwelling catheter (IDC) in place for monitoring. Output has been normal—clear urine, ~300 mL over the last 4 hours.
[DOCTOR]: Any recent bloods?
[NURSE]: Yes, FBC and electrolytes were taken this morning: Hb: 128, WCC: 7.4, Platelets: 240, Na: 136, K: 4.2, Creatinine: 76, No major abnormalities.
[DOCTOR]: Has the family been informed?
[NURSE]: Yes, I’ve spoken to her daughter. She’s on her way in and aware of the situation. I’ve reassured her that Lara is stable but still recovering.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. Let’s continue neuro obs, monitor for any further seizures, and review her antiepileptic regimen. If she has another seizure or her GCS drops, please escalate immediately.
[NURSE]: I’ll keep monitoring and update you if anything changes.

[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Thomas Reid in bed 3. He’s a 79-year-old patient with limited mobility due to a recent stroke. He has a stage 2 pressure injury on his sacrum that requires dressing today.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s the current status of the wound?
[Outgoing Nurse]: It’s a shallow ulcer with partial thickness skin loss. No slough or necrosis, but the area is red and moist. No signs of infection at this stage. The wound was last dressed yesterday with Mepilex Border, and it’s due for review and redressing this morning.
[Incoming Nurse]: What’s his Waterlow score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: His Waterlow score is 20, so he’s at very high risk. He’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and we’ve been repositioning him every 2 hours.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other monitoring or interventions?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, he has: IDC in place – draining clear urine, last emptied 2 hours ago, an IV cannula in right forearm – patent, no fluids running currently, Regular skin checks and documentation in the wound chart, his Pain score this morning was 2/10, no analgesia required
[Incoming Nurse]: Any allergies?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No known drug allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll check the wound, redress with Mepilex Border, and continue pressure care and monitoring.

[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Elaine Morris in bed 6. She’s an 84-year-old patient with reduced mobility following a recent pneumonia admission. She has a stage 2 pressure injury on her right hip.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s the current condition of the wound?
[Outgoing Nurse]: It’s a shallow ulcer with partial thickness skin loss. The wound bed is moist but clean, with no signs of infection. There’s mild erythema around the edges. The wound care nurse reviewed it this morning and recommended continuing with Allevyn Gentle Border dressing.
[Incoming Nurse]: How often does it need changing?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Every 3 days unless soiled or lifting. The next dressing change is due on Friday. We’re documenting progress in the wound chart and taking weekly photos for review.
[Incoming Nurse]: What’s her Waterlow score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Waterlow score is 18, so she’s at high risk. She’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and we’re repositioning her every 2 hours.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other relevant care?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes:  she has No IV access currently, her Oral intake is adequate, there’s No IDC, but she is continent of urine and bowels, Pain score is 1/10 at rest, no analgesia required, Skin integrity checks are ongoing, no other areas of concern
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue the pressure care, monitor the wound, and follow the dressing schedule.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Sharma, I’d like you to review Mr. David Lang in bed 11. He’s a 71-year-old patient admitted yesterday with a left-sided ischemic stroke. He’s currently stable but showing significant right-sided weakness and difficulty with coordination.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. What’s his current status?
[NURSE]: He’s alert and orientated, GCS 15. Vitals are stable: BP: 142/86, HR: 78 bpm, RR: 16, Temp: 36.7°C, SpO?: 96% on room air, Q-ADDS score: 2 for (BP + mobility). He’s mobilising with assistance but has poor upper limb function on the right. He’s struggling with feeding and grooming tasks. I think he’d benefit from an occupational therapy referral to assess for functional support and equipment.
[DOCTOR]: Any IV access?
[NURSE]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in his left forearm—patent and flushed. No IV fluids running currently.
[DOCTOR]: What medications is he on?
[NURSE]; He’s currently prescribed: Aspirin 100 mg daily, Atorvastatin 40 mg nocte, Perindopril 4 mg daily, Paracetamol 1g QID PRN for comfort. No known drug allergies.
[DOCTOR]: How is he positioned?
[NURSE]: We’re using 30-degree lateral tilt positioning to offload pressure areas and support his hemiplegic side. He’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and being repositioned every 2 hours.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. I’ll review him and put in the OT referral. Please continue neuro obs and let me know if his mobility or cognition changes.
[NURSE]: Will do. I’ll also update the allied health team and document the referral request.

[NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. David Lang in bed 11. He’s a 71-year-old patient admitted yesterday following a left-sided ischemic stroke. He’s currently stable but has significant right-sided weakness and difficulty with coordination, especially upper limb function.
[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: Thanks. What’s his current level of function?
[NURSE]: He’s alert and orientated, GCS 15. He’s mobilising with assistance but struggling with feeding, grooming, and dressing tasks. He’s right-hand dominant, which is now affected. He would benefit from an OT assessment for functional support and adaptive equipment.
[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: Any positioning or pressure care?
[NURSE]: Yes, we’re using 30-degree lateral tilt positioning to support his hemiplegic side and prevent pressure injury. He’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and repositioned every 2 hours.
[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: Any IV access or medications?
[NURSE]: He has a 20G IV cannula in his left forearm—patent, no fluids running.

[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: What about nutrition and hydration?
[NURSE]: He’s on a soft diet with thickened fluids Level 2 as per speech pathology.
Fluid balance chart shows: Input (last 24h): ~1600 mL, Output: ~1400 mL (urine), total balance: of 200 mL. He’s tolerating oral intake well with supervision.
[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: Any bowel issues?
[NURSE]: He opened his bowels this morning—formed stool, no concerns. Charted daily bowel monitoring.
[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: Thanks. I’ll assess his ADLs and see what supports we can put in place.
[NURSE]: Thanks. Let me know if you need assistance during the assessment or if any equipment needs to be ordered.

example.text:
[Hospital Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Emily Carter, a 38-year-old patient who was admitted three days ago and has now been newly diagnosed with bipolar disorder following a manic episode. She’s being discharged today and will require follow-up in the community.
[Community Nurse]: Thanks. Can you tell me a bit about her presentation?
[Hospital Nurse]: She was admitted after displaying elevated mood, pressured speech, and impulsive behaviour. No psychotic features noted. She’s now stabilised on medication and insight is improving. She’s aware of her diagnosis and has been engaging well with the mental health team.
[Community Nurse]: What’s her current medication regimen?
[Hospital Nurse]: She’s been started on: Lithium carbonate 400 mg BD – levels to be monitored, Quetiapine 300 mg nocte, PRN lorazepam 1 mg for agitation – not required in the last 48 hours there are No known drug allergies.
[Community Nurse]: Any physical health concerns?
[Hospital Nurse]: Vitals are stable. She’s independent with ADLs. No pressure areas noted. She’s been eating and drinking well, and her fluid balance is normal. Bowels have been regular.
[Community Nurse]: What’s her home situation?
[Hospital Nurse]: She lives with her husband and three children aged 4, 7, and 12, plus a dog. Her husband has been very supportive and is aware of the diagnosis. He’s keen to be involved in her care and has asked for education around mood monitoring and medication.
[Community Nurse]: Any follow-up arranged?
[Hospital Nurse]: Yes, she’s been referred to the community mental health team for ongoing support, including mood tracking, medication adherence, and psychoeducation. She’ll also need a home visit within 48 hours to assess safety and support needs.
[Community Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll follow up with the family and ensure she’s linked in with the right services.
[Hospital Nurse]: Great. Let me know if you need anything further from the inpatient team.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. James Nolan in bed 4. He’s a 67-year-old patient admitted overnight with a suspected small bowel obstruction. He’s been reviewed by the surgical team and is currently awaiting theatre—likely this afternoon.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What are his current symptoms?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s had abdominal distension, nausea, and vomiting since yesterday. No bowel movements for 48 hours. He’s nil by mouth and has an NG tube on free drainage, which has drained about 400 mL of bilious fluid since insertion.
[Incoming Nurse]: What’s his current status?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Vitals are stable: BP: 128/76, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 18, Temp: 37.2°C, SpO?: 97% on room air, Q-ADDS score: 3 (based on nausea, pain, and reduced output)
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in his right forearm—patent. He’s on IV Normal Saline at 125 mL/hr. Electrolytes are being monitored—latest bloods show mild hypokalaemia (K+ 3.2), so we’ve added potassium to his fluids.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any medications?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s charted for: IV Metoclopramide 10 mg TDS, IV Paracetamol 1g QID, PRN Morphine 2.5–5 mg SC for pain, Nil oral meds due to NBM status
[Incoming Nurse]: Any pressure care or hygiene needs?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s been in bed most of the shift. We’ve started 2-hourly repositioning and he’s on a pressure-relieving mattress. No current pressure injuries. He’ll need a full wash this morning and assistance with hygiene.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue monitoring and prep him for theatre.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Emily Carter, a 38-year-old patient who was admitted three days ago following a manic episode. She’s now been newly diagnosed with bipolar disorder and is being discharged today. I’d like to arrange home supports to help her transition safely.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thanks. Can you tell me about her current situation?
[NURSE]: She lives with her husband and three children aged 4, 7, and 12, plus a dog. Her husband is supportive but understandably overwhelmed. He’s asked for help managing the household while Emily stabilises. She’s currently well but still adjusting to the diagnosis.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: What kind of supports do you think she’ll need?
[NURSE]: She’ll benefit from: Domestic assistance (light cleaning, laundry, meal prep), Childcare support during the day, especially for the younger children, Mental health outreach for medication adherence and mood monitoring, Education for the family around bipolar disorder and crisis planning. Possibly pet care support if her condition fluctuates
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Any safety concerns?
[NURSE]: No current risks identified. She’s engaging well, has insight, and is compliant with treatment. Her husband is aware of early warning signs and has contact details for crisis support.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: What’s her medication plan?
[NURSE]:
She’s been started on: Lithium carbonate 400 mg BD, Quetiapine 300 mg nocte, PRN lorazepam 1 mg – not used in the last 48 hours, she’ll need regular lithium level monitoring and follow-up with the community mental health team.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thanks. I’ll organise a home support package and liaise with the mental health team and family services.
[NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if you need anything further from the ward team.

example.text:
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: Hi Dr. Patel, I’m handing over Mr. Anthony Reid, a 64-year-old patient who was admitted earlier today with a ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). He’s being transferred to your unit for ongoing cardiac management and potential intervention.
[Receiving Doctor]: Thanks. What’s his current status?
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: He’s currently on: IV Heparin infusion – weight-based protocol, currently running at 1000 units/hr, IV GTN infusion – titrated to chest pain, currently at 10 mcg/min, Oxygen therapy – 4 L/min via nasal prongs, saturations are sitting around 89–91% on oxygen. He’s still reporting mild chest tightness but is hemodynamically stable.
[Receiving Doctor]: Any recent observations?
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: Yes, latest obs: BP: 104/68, HR: 96 bpm, RR: 20, Temp: 36.8°C , SpO?: 91% on 4 L O?, Q-ADDS score: 6 (due to low SpO?, chest pain, and IV therapy)
[Receiving Doctor]: Any IV access?
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: Yes, he has a 16G cannula in the left antecubital fossa and a 20G in the right forearm. Both are patent and flushed. GTN and heparin are running through separate lines.
[Receiving Doctor]: Any other medications?
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]:
He’s also had: Aspirin 300 mg stat, Ticagrelor 180 mg stat, Atorvastatin 80 mg stat, Morphine 2.5 mg IV PRN – last dose was 2 hours age. No known drug allergies.
[Receiving Doctor]: Any investigations done?
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: Yes, ECG confirmed anterior STEMI. Troponin is elevated. Chest X-ray shows mild pulmonary congestion. Bloods including FBC, U&E, and coagulation profile have been sent—awaiting results.
[Receiving Doctor]: Thanks. We’ll prepare for his arrival and continue cardiac monitoring. Please send through the medication chart and infusion protocols.
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: Will do. I’ll also include his fluid balance chart and latest obs summary.

[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Daniel Brooks in bed 8. He’s a 70-year-old patient who had an angiogram and ICD placement earlier today following recurrent ventricular arrhythmias. He’s now in recovery and being monitored closely.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. How did the procedure go?
[Outgoing Nurse]: The procedure was uneventful. ICD was successfully implanted. Post-procedure ECG shows a junctional rhythm, rate around 50–60 bpm. He’s asymptomatic but under continuous cardiac monitoring.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in his left forearm, patent and flushed. No IV fluids running currently—he’s tolerating oral intake.
[Incoming Nurse]: What medications is he on?
[Outgoing Nurse]:
He’s charted for: Aspirin 100 mg daily, Bisoprolol 5 mg daily, Atorvastatin 40 mg nocte, Paracetamol 1g QID PRN he has No known drug allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any post-op care instructions?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes: Keep the ICD site dry and intact—dressing checked and clean, monitor for signs of infection or bleeding, Observe cardiac rhythm closely—junctional rhythm noted, notify cardiology if symptomatic or rate drops further, 4-hourly obs unless otherwise directed his Pain score is currently 2/10, settled with Paracetamol, and Encourage gentle mobilisation with supervision.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s alert and orientated. No nausea or dizziness. Bowels not yet open post-procedure. Fluid balance is being monitored—input ~800 mL, output ~500 mL so far.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue monitoring and escalate if rhythm changes or symptoms develop.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, I’m the incoming nurse for bed 4 my name is Peter. I’ll get handover from you now, is that okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is bed 4, Mr. Daniel Reid, mid-50s, admitted yesterday under Dr. Kumar with a Non-ST Elevation MI, confirmed as a posterior infarct on ECG and troponins.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s currently tachycardic—HR around 108—and hypotensive, BP sitting around 92/58. He’s being monitored closely. Oxygen saturations are stable at 96% on room air. His Q-ADDS score is 7, mainly due to HR, BP, and altered behaviour.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Is he scheduled for any procedures?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, he’s booked for an angiogram later today. He’s NBM and awaiting transfer to cath lab. No IV access at present—needs a cannula inserted pre-procedure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any allergies?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, he has a documented allergy to penicillin—rash and swelling reported previously.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s his current medication chart?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on: Aspirin 300 mg stat, then 100 mg daily, Ticagrelor 90 mg BD, Atorvastatin 80 mg nocte, IV fluids: Normal saline at 80 mL/hr, PRN paracetamol, No opioids charted due to substance use history.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any relevant medical history?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, Chronic back pain, Hypertension, No diabetes, No prior cardiac events, Regular cannabis use for pain, now withdrawing—he’s been restless, loud, and disruptive overnight. Behavioural charting is in place. He’s aware of the situation but fluctuates in his engagement with us. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Has Drug and Alcohol been consulted?

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Ahmed, I need you to urgently review Mr. Leonard Price in bed 10. He’s a 76-year-old patient with a history of congestive heart failure and COPD. He’s deteriorated over the last few hours with worsening shortness of breath and low oxygen saturations.
[DOCTOR]:
What’s happening currently?
[NURSE]: He’s tachypnoeic and using accessory muscles. His SpO? is 86% on 6 L via Hudson mask. He’s visibly distressed and unable to speak in full sentences. Auscultation reveals coarse crackles bilaterally. He’s likely fluid overloaded—his legs are oedematous, and his fluid balance is +1800 mL over the last 48 hours.
[DOCTOR]: What are his latest observations?
[NURSE]: BP: 158/92, HR: 112 bpm, RR: 32, Temp: 37.1°C, SpO?: 86% on 6 L O?, he’s  Alert but anxious his Q-ADDS score: 8 (SpO? + RR + HR + respiratory distress)
[DOCTOR]: Any current respiratory support?
[NURSE]: Not yet, but I believe he needs to be started on BiPAP. I’ve prepped the machine and mask. He’s not tolerating high-flow oxygen and is tiring.
[DOCTOR]: IV access?
[NURSE]: Yes, he has a 22G cannula in his right forearm, patent. No current IV fluids running. He’s on a fluid restriction chart.
[DOCTOR]: Medications?
[NURSE]:
He’s charted for: Frusemide 40 mg IV BD – last dose was this morning, Spiriva inhaler daily, PRN salbutamol neb – given 1 hour ago, Paracetamol 1g QID PRN. He has No known allergies.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. We’ll start BiPAP immediately and arrange for transfer to HDU or the respiratory unit. Please continue monitoring and notify me of any changes.
[NURSE]: Will do. I’ll document the escalation and prep for transfer.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Alan Fraser in bed 9. He’s a 74-year-old patient with acute respiratory failure secondary to COPD exacerbation. He was started on BiPAP overnight due to worsening respiratory distress and low oxygen saturations.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s his current respiratory status?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s currently on BiPAP settings: IPAP 14, EPAP 6, FiO? 40%. He’s tolerating the mask well and his SpO? is now 92%, up from 86% earlier. Respiratory rate is 24, and he’s less distressed than before.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any recent observations?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, latest obs: BP: 138/82, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 24, Temp: 36.9°C, SpO?: 92% on BiPAP and a Q-ADDS score: 6 (due to respiratory rate, oxygen requirement, and BiPAP support)
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in his left forearm, patent and flushed. No IV fluids running currently—he’s on a fluid restriction chart.
[Incoming Nurse]: What’s his fluid balance?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Input (last 24h): ~1100 mL, Output: ~800 mL urine, total balance: +300 mL. He’s been drinking small amounts with assistance.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any bloods?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, FBC taken this morning: Hb: 124, WCC: 9.2, Platelets: 210, U&E: within normal limit. No signs of infection or electrolyte imbalance.
[Incoming Nurse]: What about nutrition?
[Outgoing Nurse] He’s on a soft diet, tolerating small meals. Food chart is in progress—ate ~50% of breakfast and sipped fluids. Needs encouragement and supervision due to fatigue.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any pressure area concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No current injuries. He’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and being repositioned every 2 hours. Skin checks are ongoing—no redness or breakdown noted.
[Incoming Nurse]: Hygiene needs?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He had a full wash this morning, including oral care. He’s continent of urine and bowels—opened bowels yesterday, formed stool.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue BiPAP monitoring, pressure care, and update the food and fluid charts.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Joan Ellis in bed 2. She’s an 81-year-old patient admitted with a urinary tract infection and worsening confusion. She’s currently alert but disoriented and has been incontinent of both urine and bowels during the shift.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s her current Q-ADDS score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Her Q-ADDS score is 5—based on confusion, elevated temperature, and increased respiratory rate. Latest observations are BP: 132/78, HR: 94 bpm, RR: 22, Temp: 38.3°C, SpO?: 96% on room air, she is Alert but confused.
[Incoming Nurse]: Is she on any monitoring charts?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, a Fluid Balance Chart – she’s had ~900 mL oral intake today, and incontinent of urine twice. A Bowel Chart – opened bowels once this morning, loose stool and a Falls Risk Chart – high risk due to confusion and mobility issues.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any pressure area concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No current injuries, but she’s at risk. She’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and being repositioned every 2 hours. Skin checks are ongoing—no redness noted.
[Incoming Nurse]: What about hygiene?
[Outgoing Nurse]: She’s had a full wash this morning, including peri-care. She’ll likely need another wash later due to incontinence. Continence aids are in use.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access or medications?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No IV access currently. She’s on: Paracetamol 1g QID, IV Ceftriaxone 1g daily – given this morning, PRN lorazepam 0.5 mg – not required today
No known allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue monitoring, update the charts, and assist with hygiene as needed.

example.text:
[NURSE 1]: Hey, I’m handing over Sarah Nguyen, 29 years old, came into ED earlier today with acute abdominal pain — mainly in the right lower quadrant. She’s currently awaiting surgical review.
[NURSE 2]: Okay, thanks. What’s her current status?
[NURSE 1]: Vitals are stable — temp 37.8°C, HR 88, BP 118/76, RR 18, SpO? 99% on room air. Pain is sitting at 6/10, managed with IV analgesia. She’s nil by mouth pending review.
[NURSE 2]: Any imaging done?
[NURSE 1]: Yes, she’s had an abdominal ultrasound — inconclusive. CT abdomen is booked for this afternoon. Bloods show mild leukocytosis, CRP elevated. Urine is clear, pregnancy test negative.
[NURSE 2]: Any IV access?
[NURSE 1]: Yep, 20G in the left antecubital fossa — patent. She’s had IV fluids and analgesia. No known allergies.
[NURSE 2]: Any behavioural concerns?
[NURSE 1]: No concerns. She’s alert, oriented, and coping well. Just anxious about the possibility of surgery.
[NURSE 2]: Got it. Anything else I need to follow up?
[NURSE 1]: Just keep an eye on her pain and nausea. Surgical team should be around shortly. Let me know if anything changes.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over details for Mr. Luke Harris, a 42-year-old male who presented to ED following a deliberate overdose. He reportedly ingested approximately 50 Panadol tablets, 20 Serepax, and a bottle of whisky at home.
[PHARMACIST]: Thanks. What’s his current status?
[NURSE]: He’s currently drowsy but rousable, with slurred speech and intermittent agitation. He’s on 2 L/min oxygen via nasal prongs, with SpO? around 92%. GCS is 13. He’s under close observation and has IV access in place.
[PHARMACIST]: Have any treatments been initiated?
[NURSE]: Yes, we’ve started IV fluids (Normal Saline) and taken bloods for paracetamol levels, LFTs, and coagulation profile. We’re awaiting results to determine if N-acetylcysteine is required. No activated charcoal was given due to delayed presentation and reduced consciousness.
[PHARMACIST]: Any known allergies or regular medications?
[NURSE]: No known drug allergies. No regular medications documented at this stage. He’s a daily smoker and reports high alcohol intake.
[PHARMACIST]: Any concerns about interactions or toxicity?
[NURSE]: Yes, we’re concerned about hepatotoxicity from paracetamol, sedation from Serepax, and CNS depression from alcohol. He’s being monitored for respiratory compromise and liver function deterioration.
[PHARMACIST]: Thanks. I’ll review his chart and prepare for possible NAC administration. Let me know once the blood results are back.
[NURSE]: Will do. I’ll keep you updated on his clinical status and any changes.

[ED Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Luke Harris, a 42-year-old male who presented to ED following a deliberate overdose. He reportedly ingested approximately 50 Panadol tablets, 20 Serepax, and a bottle of whisky at home after an argument with his partner.
[Paramedic]: Thanks. What’s his current condition?
[ED Nurse]: He arrived via ambulance, drowsy but rousable. He’s currently confused, slurred speech, and intermittently agitated. He’s on 2 L/min oxygen via nasal prongs, but his SpO? is sitting around 92%. He’s a smoker, and his respiratory rate is slightly depressed at 10–12 breaths per minute.
[Paramedic]: Any vitals or Q-ADDS score?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, latest observations: BP: 118/76, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 12, Temp: 36.5°C, SpO?: 92% on 2 L O?, GCS: 13 and a Q-ADDS score: 6 (due to RR, SpO?, confusion, and overdose)
[Paramedic]: Any IV access or treatment started?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in his right forearm, patent. We’ve started IV fluids (Normal Saline) and drawn bloods for paracetamol levels, LFTs, and coagulation profile. Activated charcoal was not given due to delayed presentation and reduced consciousness.
[Paramedic]: Any social concerns?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he lives with his partner and has been in a verbal altercation prior to the overdose. He has no known mental health diagnosis, but this appears to be a first-time overdose. He has no children at home but reports high alcohol use and smoking daily.
[Paramedic]: Any plans for transfer?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he’s being transferred to the medical ward for monitoring and possible N-acetylcysteine infusion pending paracetamol levels. Mental health team will review once medically stable.
[Paramedic]: Okay, I’ll update the receiving team and ensure safe transfer.

[ED Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Luke Harris, a 42-year-old male who presented to ED earlier today following a deliberate overdose. He reportedly ingested approximately 50 Panadol tablets, 20 Serepax, and a bottle of whisky after a fight with his partner.
[Drug & Alcohol Nurse]: Thanks. What’s his current condition?
[ED Nurse]: He’s currently drowsy but rousable, with slurred speech, intermittent agitation, and low oxygen saturations—around 92% on 2 L nasal prongs. GCS is 13. He’s under close observation and has IV access in place. Bloods have been taken for paracetamol levels, LFTs, and coagulation profile. We’re awaiting results to determine if NAC is required.
[Drug & Alcohol Nurse]: Any known substance use history?
[ED Nurse]: He’s a daily smoker and reports heavy alcohol use, especially during periods of stress. No documented history of drug use, but this is his first known overdose. He’s not currently linked in with any mental health or addiction services.
[Drug & Alcohol Nurse]: Any social concerns?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he lives with his partner, and the overdose occurred following a verbal altercation. He’s currently not safe to discharge and will need a mental health review once medically stable. No children at home, but he’s expressed feelings of hopelessness and anger.
[Drug & Alcohol Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll assess him once he’s more alert and begin planning for support post-discharge, including possible referral to AOD services and counselling.
[ED Nurse]: Perfect. Let me know if you need anything from the medical team or if you’d like to join the MDT review later today.

example.text:
[NURSE 1]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Alan Roberts, 76 years old. He’s on the ward with a Stage 2 pressure injury on his right shoulder. Wound care is ongoing.
[NURSE 2]: Okay, thanks. What’s the current wound management plan?
[NURSE 1]: The area is dressed with a hydrocolloid dressing, changed every 72 hours or as needed. No signs of infection — no redness or discharge. Tissue viability nurse has reviewed and documented the plan.
[NURSE 2]: Got it. Any pain or discomfort?
[NURSE 1]: He reports mild discomfort during dressing changes but otherwise tolerating well. Analgesia charted PRN — he had paracetamol this morning.
[NURSE 2]: Any IV access?
[NURSE 1]: Yes, 22G cannula in the left forearm. It’s patent, no signs of phlebitis. Due for review tomorrow — charted for removal if no longer needed.
[NURSE 2]: I’ll check the site during rounds. Any meds due?
[NURSE 1]: No meds due right now. He’s on oral antibiotics — started two days ago for a UTI, due to complete in three more days. No known drug allergies.
[NURSE 2]: Any behavioural or cognitive concerns?
[NURSE 1]: No concerns. He’s alert, oriented, and engaging well. Mobilising with assistance. Pressure area care chart is up to date.
[NURSE 2]: Great, I’ll keep an eye on the wound and IV site. Let me know if anything changes.

[NURSE 1]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. David Lee, 64 years old. He’s on the ward post-lobectomy and currently has a left-sided ICC in situ. It’s due to come out today.
[NURSE 2]: Okay, thanks. What’s the current status of the ICC?
[NURSE 1]: ICC has been on free drainage. Output over the last 24 hours is minimal — around 20 mL serous fluid. No air leak noted. Chest X-ray this morning shows good lung expansion. Surgical team reviewed and gave the okay for removal.
[NURSE 2]: Got it. Any pain or discomfort?
[NURSE 1]: He’s had some mild discomfort around the insertion site, but it’s well managed with regular paracetamol. No signs of infection — site is clean and dry.
[NURSE 2]: Any IV access?
[NURSE 1]: Yes, 20G cannula in the right forearm — patent and due for review tomorrow. He’s currently on oral meds only.
[NURSE 2]: I’ll check the med chart. Anything due?
[NURSE 1]: No meds due right now. He’s on regular analgesia and a stool softener. No known allergies.
[NURSE 2]: Any behavioural or cognitive concerns?
[NURSE 1]: No concerns. He’s alert, oriented, and understands the plan. He’s a bit anxious about the ICC removal, so just reassure him and let him know we’ll use local anaesthetic.
[NURSE 2]: Will do. I’ll prep the trolley and notify the team once it’s out.

example.text:
[ED Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Jack Thompson, a 45-year-old male who presented to ED following a chainsaw injury to his left lower leg sustained while working in forestry. The injury occurred approximately 90 minutes ago on-site.
[Paramedic]: Thanks. What’s his current condition?
[ED Nurse]: He’s alert and orientated, GCS 15. He’s in moderate pain but stable. The wound is deep, located on the anterolateral aspect of the left lower leg, with visible muscle and tissue damage. No active arterial bleeding, but there was significant blood loss at the scene.
[Paramedic]: Any neurovascular compromise?
[ED Nurse]:
We’ve done neurovascular obs: Sensation: Intact distal to the wound, Motor: Able to move toes, reduced strength in dorsiflexion, Capillary refill: less than 2 seconds, Pedal pulses: Present but slightly diminished compared to the right, Skin temp: Warm distally
We’re monitoring closely for compartment syndrome.
[Paramedic]: Any IV access?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he has a 16G cannula in the right antecubital fossa, patent. He’s received 1 L Normal Saline IV and IV morphine 5 mg for pain relief.
[Paramedic]: Any other treatment so far?
[ED Nurse]: The wound has been irrigated and dressed with sterile gauze. Tetanus status is unknown—awaiting confirmation. Bloods have been taken including FBC, coagulation, and crossmatch. He’s Nil by mouth and awaiting surgical review.
[Paramedic]: Any other concerns?
[ED Nurse]: He’s a smoker, no known drug allergies, and has no significant medical history. He’s anxious but cooperative. We’ve contacted his workplace and next of kin.
[Paramedic]: Thanks. I’ll ensure safe transfer and continue monitoring neurovascular status en route

example.text:
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Hi there, I’m bringing in Mr. Jason Taylor, 34 years old. He’s been picked up from home following a welfare check requested by his GP. He’s known to have schizophrenia and is currently experiencing an acute psychotic episode.
[ED NURSE]: What’s been happening?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: He’s been verbally aggressive, paranoid, and disorganised in speech. He believes people are trying to harm him and has been refusing food and medication for the past few days. No physical aggression during transport, but he’s restless and pacing.
[ED NURSE]: Any injuries or medical concerns?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: No injuries. Vitals are within acceptable range: BP: 118/76 , HR: 92, RR: 20, Temp: 36.9°C, SpO?: 97% on room air.
[ED NURSE]: Any known medications or allergies?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: He’s prescribed olanzapine but I don't think he’s been taking it. He has a documented allergy to penicillin—rash and swelling reported previously.
[ED NURSE]: Any substance use?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Yes, he’s a regular cannabis user for anxiety and sleep, but he’s currently withdrawing—reports irritability and insomnia. GP flagged this as contributing to his current state. A Drug and Alcohol Team review is recommended.
[ED NURSE]: Is he medically cleared?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: He’s stable but needs a mental health assessment. No IV access yet—may need a cannula inserted if sedation or fluids are required. He’s not cooperative with physical exams. He is also under the mental health act.
[ED NURSE]: Thanks. We’ll get him triaged and notify the Mental Health Liaison Team. If needed, we’ll escalate for admission to the Mental Health Unit.
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Perfect. He’s currently in the waiting area with security nearby. Let me know if you need anything else.

preds.quote: Hi there, I’m bringing in Mr. Jason Taylor, 34 years old. He’s been picked up from home following a welfare check requested by his GP. He’s known to have schizophrenia and is currently experiencing an acute psychotic episode.

preds.label: ASSESSMENT
preds.quote: He’s been verbally aggressive, paranoid, and disorganised in speech. He believes people are trying to harm him and has been refusing food and medication for the past few days. No physical aggression during transport, but he’s restless and pacing.

preds.label: ASSESSMENT
preds.quote: No injuries. Vitals are within acceptable range: BP: 118/76 , HR: 92, RR: 20, Temp: 36.9°C, SpO?: 97% on room air.

preds.label: BACKGROUND
preds.quote: He’s prescribed olanzapine but I don't think he’s been taking it. He has a documented allergy to penicillin—rash and swelling reported previously.

preds.label: BACKGROUND
preds.quote: Yes, he’s a regular cannabis user for anxiety and sleep, but he’s currently withdrawing—reports irritability and insomnia. GP flagged this as contributing to his current state.

preds.label: RECOMMENDATION
preds.quote: A Drug and Alcohol Team review is recommended.

preds.label: ASSESSMENT
preds.quote: He’s stable but needs a mental health assessment. No IV access yet—may need a cannula inserted if sedation or fluids are required. He’s not cooperative with physical exams. He is also under the mental health act.

preds.label: RECOMMENDATION
preds.quote: We’ll get him triaged and notify the Mental Health Liaison Team. If needed, we’ll escalate for admission to the Mental Health Unit.

preds.label: ASSESSMENT
preds.quote: He’s currently in the waiting area with security nearby.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Dorothy Lane in bed 5. She’s an 83-year-old patient admitted with a left neck of femur fracture following a fall at home. She’s post-op day 1 following internal fixation. She’s currently confused, intermittently orientated, and requires full assistance with care.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s her current Q-ADDS score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Her Q-ADDS score is 5—due to confusion, elevated respiratory rate, and low urine output. Latest observations: BP: 118/72, HR: 96 bpm, RR: 22, Temp: 36.9°C, SpO?: 95% on room air, she’s Alert but confused.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any pressure area concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, she has a chronic venous leg ulcer on her right lower leg. It’s being dressed with Iodosorb and a foam dressing, reviewed by wound care yesterday. No sacral or heel breakdown noted. She’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and being repositioned every 2 hours.
[Incoming Nurse]: Is she continent?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No, she’s incontinent of urine and has an IDC in place—draining clear urine, ~400 mL over the last 6 hours. She’s also on a bowel chart—no bowel movement today, last opened bowels yesterday.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any vascular obs?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, we’re doing neurovascular obs on the affected limb: Sensation: Intact, Movement: Limited due to pain, Cap refill: less than 2 seconds, Pedal pulses: Present, Skin temp: Warm.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access or medications?
[Outgoing Nurse]: She has a 20G cannula in her right forearm, patent.
Medications include: IV Cefazolin 1g TDS, Paracetamol 1g QID, PRN Endone 2.5–5 mg Enoxaparin 40 mg SC daily, No known drug allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue pressure care, monitor her Q-ADDS, and update wound and fluid charts.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Patel, I need you to review Mr. Raymond Ellis in bed 6. He’s a 68-year-old patient with severe systolic heart failure; EF is 20% on echo. He’s currently being monitored for ventricular arrhythmias and has an irregular heart rate. Cardiology has flagged him for ICD placement pending further assessment.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. What’s his current clinical status?
[NURSE]: He’s on dobutamine at 5 mcg/kg/min and dopamine at 3 mcg/kg/min for inotropic support. He’s on continuous cardiac monitoring—rhythm is irregular, mostly junctional with occasional ectopics. He’s alert but fatigued.
[DOCTOR]: What are his latest observations?
[NURSE]: BP: 94/58, HR: 108 bpm, irregular, RR: 22, Temp: 36.6°C, SpO?: 94% on 2 L O?, and a Q-ADDS score: 7 (HR, BP, RR, cardiac rhythm).
[DOCTOR]: Any fluid balance concerns?
[NURSE]: Yes, he’s fluid overloaded. His Input (last 24h): ~2200 mL (IV + oral) the Output: ~1200 mL (IDC), the total balance:  plus 1000 mL
He’s on a fluid restriction chart and daily weights. Legs are oedematous and he’s on 2-hourly pressure area care with a pressure-relieving mattress.
[DOCTOR]: Any other monitoring?
[NURSE]: Yes, we’re doing neurovascular obs and cardiac telemetry. He has a 22G cannula in the left forearm, patent. IDC is draining clear urine. No bowel movement today—on a bowel chart.
[DOCTOR]: Medications?
[NURSE]: IV Dobutamine & Dopamine as mentioned, Frusemide 40 mg IV BD, Bisoprolol 2.5 mg daily, Spironolactone 25 mg daily, Paracetamol 1g QID PRN
No known drug allergies.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. I’ll review him now and speak with cardiology regarding ICD timing and ongoing inotropic support.
[NURSE]: Great. I’ll continue monitoring and update fluid and Q-ADDS charts.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Singh, I need to speak with you about Mr. Jason Cole in bed 7. He’s a 49-year-old patient admitted yesterday with a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). He’s now requesting to self-discharge against medical advice.
[DOCTOR]: Okay. What’s prompting the request?
[NURSE]: He’s frustrated and says he “feels fine” and wants to go home. He’s been arguing with staff and mentioned needing to “sort things out” with his partner. He’s also expressed discomfort with being in hospital and says he doesn’t want to stay another night.
[DOCTOR]: Any safety concerns?
[NURSE]: Yes. He’s still on aspirin and enoxaparin and has not yet had his cardiology review. He’s a daily smoker and disclosed regular cannabis use. He’s currently on 2 L oxygen via nasal prongs, with SpO? sitting around 93%. He’s intermittently short of breath and still reporting mild chest tightness.
[DOCTOR]: What are his latest observations?
[NURSE]: BP: 132/84, HR: 102 bpm, RR: 20, Temp: 36.8°C, SpO?: 93% on 2 L O? and Q-ADDS score: 6 (due to HR, SpO?, and chest symptoms)
[DOCTOR]: Has he been informed of the risks?
[NURSE]: I’ve explained the risks of leaving before cardiology clearance, including potential for arrhythmia or further cardiac events. He’s aware but says he’s “not staying.” I’ve started the Against Medical Advice documentation and flagged it with the nurse unit manager.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. I’ll speak with him directly and assess capacity. If he’s determined to leave, we’ll need to complete the discharge summary and safety netting advice.
[NURSE]:
Understood. I’ll keep monitoring and let you know if his condition changes.

example.text:
[Hospital Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Harold Bennett, a 79-year-old resident from Greenview Aged Care Facility. He was admitted 5 days ago with a chest infection and is now medically stable and ready for discharge back to the nursing home.
[Nursing Home Nurse]: Thanks. What’s his current condition?
[Hospital Nurse]: He’s alert and orientated, though mildly fatigued. He’s completed a course of IV antibiotics—ceftriaxone—and has now transitioned to oral amoxicillin 500 mg TDS, which he’ll continue for another 3 days. His SpO? is 96% on room air, and he’s no longer requiring supplemental oxygen.
[Nursing Home Nurse]: Any ongoing care needs?
[Hospital Nurse]: Yes:  he needs Pressure area care: He’s at moderate risk (Waterlow score 16), so continue 2-hourly repositioning and maintain use of a pressure-relieving mattress. His Fluid balance chart shows he’s been drinking well, no IV fluids required. Input ~1600 mL/day, output ~1400 mL/day. The Bowel chart:  shows his Last bowel movement was yesterday—formed stool. Continue monitoring. He’s Mobilising with assistance. Physiotherapy has recommended gentle walking with a frame. His Q-ADDS score: Currently 2 (mild fatigue and recent infection). Continue routine obs twice daily unless deterioration.
[Nursing Home Nurse]: Any medications or allergies?
[Hospital Nurse]: He’s on: Amoxicillin 500 mg TDS (3 days remaining), Paracetamol 1g QID PRN, Atorvastatin 20 mg nocte, he has No known drug allergies.
[Nursing Home Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue monitoring and update the GP if needed.
[Hospital Nurse]: Perfect. Discharge summary and medication chart are with the transfer paperwork. Let me know if you need anything further.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Kyle Jensen in bed 3. He’s a 29-year-old male admitted through ED last night following a stab wound to the left lower abdomen. He’s currently stable but requires ongoing wound care and IV medications.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s the current status of the wound?
[Outgoing Nurse]: The wound is approximately 4 cm in length, deep but not penetrating any major organs. It was cleaned and sutured in ED. There’s mild swelling and bruising around the site, but no signs of active bleeding or infection. Dressing is intact and due for review this afternoon.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any neurovascular concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Neurovascular obs are normal his Sensation and movement in lower limbs are intact, the Capillary refill less than 2 seconds, and there are No signs of vascular compromise.
[Incoming Nurse]: What medications is he on?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s currently on: IV Ceftriaxone 1g daily, IV Paracetamol 1g QID, PRN Morphine 2.5–5 mg SC for pain he has No known drug allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other monitoring?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes: a Fluid Balance Chart: Input ~1200 mL, Output ~900 mL (urine via voiding), he has a Q-ADDS score: Currently 3 (due to pain and elevated HR) His vitals are stable. 
[Incoming Nurse]: Any psychosocial concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s cooperative but anxious. Police have been notified due to the nature of the injury. No visitors currently. Social work referral has been made.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue wound care, monitor his IV therapy, and update his charts.

example.text:
NURSE: Dr. Lee, Mr. Matthews arrested about 40 minutes ago. We initiated CPR immediately and followed the ALS protocol. He was in asystole throughout. Despite full resuscitation efforts, we were unable to regain a pulse. Time of death was recorded at 11:42 AM.
DOCTOR: Thanks for the update. Were the family contacted?
NURSE: Yes, his wife and daughter are here now. They’re in the quiet room. I’ve let them know there was a serious deterioration, but they don’t know he’s passed yet.
DOCTOR: Alright. Let’s speak with them together. I’ll lead the conversation, and you can support with any nursing or practical details.
