[NURSE]: Good morning, Dr. Chen. I’d like to hand over Mr. Robert Hayes in bed 12. He’s a 72-year-old patient with congestive heart failure, admitted three days ago with worsening dyspnoea and peripheral oedema. His ejection fraction is 30%, confirmed on echo.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. Mr. Hayes, how are you feeling this morning?
[PATIENT]: Still a bit short of breath, especially when I move around. My legs feel heavy.
[NURSE]: He’s been on IV frusemide 40 mg BD, and we’ve seen some improvement in his fluid balance. His Input (last 24h) is  1200 mL his Output is  1800 mL via IDC. His total balance is -600 mL. He’s on a fluid restriction of 1.5 L/day and a low-sodium diet.
[DOCTOR]: Any changes in observations?
[NURSE]: Yes, latest obs: BP: 110/70, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 20, SpO?: 94% on room air, Temp: 36.7°C and a Q-ADDS score:  of 4 (due to RR and ongoing symptoms). He’s been repositioned 2-hourly, and we’re maintaining pressure area care with a pressure-relieving mattress. No skin breakdown noted.
[DOCTOR]: Any concerns with medications or tolerance?
[NURSE]: He’s tolerating oral meds well he has No known drug allergies.
[PATIENT]: Doctor, do you think I’ll be going home soon?
[DOCTOR]: We’re seeing good progress, Mr. Hayes. We’ll continue monitoring your fluid status and symptoms. If things keep improving, we’ll start planning for discharge with community follow-up.
[NURSE]: I’ll continue monitoring his Q-ADDS, fluid balance, and skin integrity. Would you like a repeat blood panel today?
[DOCTOR]: Yes, let’s check renal function and electrolytes again. Thanks.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Wong. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Wong. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Lumin Wong.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Mr. Lumin Wong in Bed 3, Room 12, aged 75, under Dr. Liu.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mr. Wong is awaiting CABG surgery. He’s currently on a heparin infusion for anticoagulation and a GTN infusion for chest pain. Both infusions are running as per protocol. His vitals have remained stable overnight.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s nil by mouth and aware of the pending surgery. No new symptoms or concerns reported during this shift.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Wong, have you had any chest pain or other symptoms overnight?
[PATIENT]: No, I’ve been okay. Just waiting for the surgery.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No complaints noted. The surgical team hasn’t provided an update yet on the timing, but we’ll continue to follow up.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check in with Dr. Liu’s team and let you know as soon as we hear anything. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and review your chart, Mr. Wong.

example.text:
[ED NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Maria Santos, 58 years old, coming up to the ward with cellulitis on her left lower leg. She’s been started on IV antibiotics and is stable for transfer.
[WARD NURSE]: Thanks. What’s her current status?
[ED NURSE]: Vitals are stable — temp 37.6°C, HR 84, BP 122/78, RR 18, SpO? 98% on room air. The affected leg is red, warm, and swollen from mid-calf to ankle. No signs of abscess or necrosis.
[WARD NURSE]: Okay. What’s the antibiotic plan?
[ED NURSE]: She’s on IV cefazolin, 1g every 8 hours. First dose was given in ED about an hour ago. Next dose is due at 10 PM. No known drug allergies.
[WARD NURSE]: Got it. Any IV access?
[ED NURSE]: Yes, 20G cannula in the right forearm — site is clean, dry, and patent. Charted for daily review. She’s also had IV fluids earlier, but now tolerating oral intake.
[WARD NURSE]: Any pain management?
[ED NURSE]: She’s had paracetamol 1g orally — pain is currently 4/10. PRN analgesia is charted.
[WARD NURSE]: Any behavioural or cognitive concerns?
[ED NURSE]: No concerns. She’s alert, oriented, and understands the treatment plan. Mobilising with assistance due to leg discomfort.
[WARD NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll check the IV site and meds when she arrives. Let me know if anything changes before transfer.

His drain output has been recorded and remains within expected range. He’s tolerating sips of water and has been reviewed by the surgical team this morning.

[PATIENT]: A little sore, but manageable. I was able to sit out with the physio earlier.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s great. He mobilised to the chair with assistance and tolerated it well. Physio will return later today to continue with breathing exercises and early mobilisation.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up with the physio team and check your pain relief before their next visit. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay for now.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m the incoming nurse for bed 6, my name is Cath. Can I get handover now?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Sure. This is bed 6, Sarah Thompson, 24 years old. She was admitted last night under Dr. Malik following a mental health assessment in ED. She’s presenting with severe depressive symptoms and suicidal ideation.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her symptoms have worsened since the death of her mother from breast cancer about six weeks ago. She’s been socially withdrawn, tearful, and expressing feelings of hopelessness. She disclosed thoughts of ending her life but no current plan or attempt.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any dependents?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she has a 3-year-old daughter who is currently staying with extended family. She’s expressed guilt and distress about not being able to care for her child.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any substance use?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s a daily smoker, no other substances reported. No alcohol or drug use disclosed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any medical history?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No chronic physical health conditions. No previous psychiatric admissions, but she has a history of low mood and anxiety since adolescence. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How has she been overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Settled but emotionally fragile. She’s been quiet, cooperative with care, but tearful during interactions. No behavioural incidents. She’s on 15-minute observations due to suicide risk.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any medications charted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]:
She’s started on: Sertraline 50 mg daily, Temazepam 10 mg PRN for sleep, Paracetamol PRN, No antipsychotics or mood stabilisers at this stage. She has no side effects to Sertraline, and her sleep has been good, and she is not sedated.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any referrals?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she’s been referred to the psychologist and social worker for grief counselling and parenting support. Child Safety has been notified due to her current mental state and care arrangements.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll continue close monitoring and follow up with the allied health team.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything escalates. She’s currently resting in her room.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Harris. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Harris. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Thomas Harris.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Mr. Thomas Harris in Bed 5, Room 11, aged 45, under Dr. Singh, General Surgeon.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mr. Harris is Day 2 post-op from an open appendectomy for a perforated appendix. He has a surgical drain in situ, which has drained 80 mL of serous fluid overnight. He’s currently on IV antibiotics and analgesia. He remains nil by mouth and is receiving IV fluids.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s had mild abdominal discomfort but no nausea or vomiting. Observations have been stable. Wound site is clean, dressing intact. Surgical team reviewed him this morning and will reassess drain output tomorrow.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was seen by physiotherapy yesterday afternoon and assisted to sit out of bed. He tolerated mobilisation well but reported mild dizziness. Breathing exercises were commenced.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Harris, how are you feeling this morning? Any pain or nausea?
[PATIENT]: A bit sore and tired, but no nausea.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pain score was 4/10 on movement earlier. No new concerns noted. Dr. Singh is happy with progress so far and will review again tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up with the physio team and surgical team regarding the drain and mobility. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and review your chart, Mr. Harris.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Ms. Taylor. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Taylor. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Olivia Taylor.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Olivia Taylor in Bed 7, Room 15, aged 38, under Dr. Chen, Emergency Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Taylor presented to ED last night following an assault at home by her intoxicated husband. She has bruising to her left eye and forearm, and a minor laceration to her scalp, which has been cleaned and dressed. CT head was clear. Vitals stable overnight. She’s alert and oriented.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Taylor disclosed that her children are currently at school and she is concerned for their safety. She has not returned home and is unsure of her next steps.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ms. Taylor, how are you feeling this morning? Any pain or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: Just sore and tired. I’m worried about my kids.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Understandably. Pain score was 5/10 earlier. She’s had oral analgesia and is tolerating fluids. No nausea or vomiting. A social worker was contacted and will be attending shortly to support safety planning and discuss options.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Hi Olivia, I’m Sarah, one of the hospital social workers. I understand you’ve had a very difficult night. I’m here to support you. Would it be okay if we talked for a few minutes?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s okay.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thank you. First, I want to check—are you feeling safe right now? Is your husband aware you’re here?
[PATIENT]: No, he was drunk and passed out when I left. I don’t think he knows.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Okay. We can help ensure your safety while you're here and support you with options for accommodation, legal advice, and child protection if needed. Would you like us to contact someone on your behalf—family, a friend, or a support service?
[PATIENT]: Maybe my sister. She’s in Brisbane.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Absolutely. I’ll help you with that. We’ll also work with the team to make sure your children are safe and supported. You're not alone in this.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Bennett. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Rachel Bennett.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Rachel Bennett in Bed 2, Room 9, aged 52, under Dr. Wallace, Oncology Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Bennett is currently receiving cycle 3 of chemotherapy for breast cancer. She’s had mild nausea overnight, managed with antiemetics. Her vitals are stable, and she’s tolerating oral fluids. Bloods were taken this morning for routine monitoring.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s expressed feeling emotionally overwhelmed and worried about managing work and home responsibilities during treatment. A social worker referral was made, and they’re scheduled to visit later this morning.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Hi Rachel, I’m Priya, one of the hospital social workers. I understand you’re going through a lot right now, and I’m here to support you. Is it okay if we talk for a few minutes?
[PATIENT]: Yes, please. I’ve been struggling a bit.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thank you. I know chemotherapy can be physically and emotionally exhausting. You mentioned concerns about work and home—can you tell me a bit more about what’s been difficult?
[PATIENT]: I’m a single mum, and I’ve had to take time off work. I’m worried about bills and keeping things stable for my daughter.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: That’s completely understandable. We can explore options for financial support, community services, and counselling. I can also help connect you with support groups for women going through similar experiences. Would that be helpful?
[PATIENT]: Yes, I think so. I just don’t know where to start.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: That’s okay—I'll walk you through it. You’re not alone in this, and we’ll make sure you have the support you need.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check back in shortly, Ms. Bennett, and coordinate with Priya and Dr. Wallace’s team. Please use the call bell if you need anything.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Davies. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Davies. This is Emma the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Michael Davies.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. And your date of birth? [PATIENT]: First July 1985. [OUTGOING_NURSE]: And your URN on the armband is 231879, which is what I have on the chart. So, Mr. Davies is under Dr. Kumar from Infectious Diseases — who I think will be the consultant covering this week. Mr. Davies was admitted yesterday with what seems to be acute gastroenteritis, most likely secondary to rotavirus infection. He’s currently being barrier nursed in isolation. Full PPE is required before entering — though I think they were short on gowns earlier, so check the supply trolley just in case. He’s on contact precautions, given the transmission risk.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s had several episodes of diarrhoea overnight — not sure how many. Managed with oral rehydration and IV fluids. No vomiting that I’m aware of. Stool sample was sent and the initial report suggests rotavirus, but the full panel isn’t back yet.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s tolerating small sips of water and bits of dry toast this morning. No abdominal pain reported, though he mentioned feeling “a little off” earlier. Continence aids are in use, and environmental services were notified for enhanced cleaning last night, but I’m not completely sure if they’ve been through yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Davies, how are you feeling this morning? Any nausea or cramping?
[PATIENT]: A bit tired, but no pain. Just still needing the bathroom a lot.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Okay, thanks. He’s aware of the need to remain in isolation and has mostly been cooperative with infection control steps. No visitors allowed at this stage, though I think his partner’s been trying to contact the ward. Dr. Kumar should be reviewing later today — I’m not sure of the exact time yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thank you. I’ll keep monitoring his fluids, stool frequency, and general symptoms, and check in again after the review. If there’s any issue with supplies or isolation process, I’ll raise it with infection control.
[PATIENT]: No problem.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mr. Davies. Please use your call bell if you need anything. I’ll be finishing up my shift shortly.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, I’ll be back soon to recheck your obs and update your chart.

preds.label: ASSESSMENT
preds.quote: He’s had several episodes of diarrhoea overnight — not sure how many. Managed with oral rehydration and IV fluids. No vomiting that I’m aware of. Stool sample was sent and the initial report suggests rotavirus, but the full panel isn’t back yet.

preds.label: ASSESSMENT
preds.quote: He’s tolerating small sips of water and bits of dry toast this morning. No abdominal pain reported, though he mentioned feeling “a little off” earlier. Continence aids are in use, and environmental services were notified for enhanced cleaning last night, but I’m not completely sure if they’ve been through yet.

preds.label: ASSESSMENT
preds.quote: He’s aware of the need to remain in isolation and has mostly been cooperative with infection control steps. No visitors allowed at this stage, though I think his partner’s been trying to contact the ward. Dr. Kumar should be reviewing later today — I’m not sure of the exact time yet.

preds.label: RECOMMENDATION
preds.quote: I’ll keep monitoring his fluids, stool frequency, and general symptoms, and check in again after the review. If there’s any issue with supplies or isolation process, I’ll raise it with infection control.

preds.label: RECOMMENDATION
preds.quote: Please use your call bell if you need anything.

preds.label: RECOMMENDATION
preds.quote: I’ll be back soon to recheck your obs and update your chart.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mr. Thompson was brought into ED yesterday by his wife due to severe constipation and abdominal discomfort. He had not opened his bowels for 6 days and was experiencing bloating and reduced appetite. His wife, who is also elderly, was struggling to manage his care at home.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was assessed in ED, given a fleet enema and started on oral laxatives. Abdominal X-ray showed significant faecal loading but no obstruction. He’s now admitted for bowel management and monitoring. Vitals are stable. No nausea or vomiting overnight.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s had one small bowel motion early this morning. Pain score was 3/10. He’s tolerating fluids and has been mobilising with assistance.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Thompson, how are you feeling this morning? Any relief after the bowel motion?
[PATIENT]: A little better, still a bit uncomfortable.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s aware of the plan and has been cooperative. His wife is quite anxious and has asked to speak with someone about support at home. A social worker referral has been made to assess home care needs and carer support.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up with the social work team and check in with Dr. Ellis’s team regarding next steps. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and review your chart, Mr. Thompson.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Fraser. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s alright.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Fraser. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Andrew Fraser.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you and your date of birth? 
[PATIENT]: Twenty-third of August 1958. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great and your URN on that armband says 893745 that matches your chart. So Mr Fraser is under the cardiothoracic surgeon covering this list - not sure who.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was admitted yesterday for a planned aortic valve replacement due to severe aortic stenosis. He’s currently stable, nil by mouth, and awaiting theatre — I think the procedure’s still set for this afternoon, though final time hasn’t been confirmed yet. Pre‑op bloods and ECG were done and look okay from what I saw, but anaesthetics still need to recheck his potassium levels. Consent’s signed and documented.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on his regular cardiac medications — they were reviewed by the anaesthetics registrar this morning, or possibly one of the fellows. No chest pain or shortness of breath that he’s mentioned overnight. Vitals all fine — around baseline. He’s aware of the procedure and quite anxious, understandably; I reassured him but might be worth chatting again before transfer.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Fraser, how are you feeling this morning? Any discomfort or anything worrying you?
[PATIENT]: Just nervous, really. No pain.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Of course. His wife’s planning to come in later today — she wasn’t sure what time yet. Theatre team should ring the ward once they’ve finalised scheduling, but I haven’t heard back this morning. He’s got family contact details in the chart if anyone needs to update them.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll follow up with the surgical team and confirm timing when possible. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great. Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll be finishing soon, but the coordinator’s around if anything changes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. I’ll come back shortly to check your obs and review your chart, Mr. Fraser.

example.text:
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Hi there, I’m bringing in Mrs. Margaret Ellis, 87 years old, from Rosewood Nursing Home. She had a fall earlier this morning—staff found her on the floor next to her bed. She’s hit her head, and there’s a small occipital hematoma. No loss of consciousness reported, but she’s been drowsy and confused since.
[ED NURSE]: Thanks. Any known medical history?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Yes, she has: Hypertension, Osteoarthritis, Early-stage dementia and a Profound hearing loss – she’s deaf and communicates via written notes and gestures. No hearing aids in place today.
[ED NURSE]: Any medications or allergies?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: She’s on amlodipine and paracetamol regularly. No known drug allergies.
[ED NURSE]: What’s her current condition?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]:
Vitals on arrival: BP: 102/64, HR: 88, RR: 18, Temp: 36.7°C, SpO?: 97% on room air
She’s responsive but confused. No vomiting. GCS is 14.
[ED NURSE]: Any advanced care directives?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Yes, nursing home staff provided documentation indicating a Do Not Resuscitate (DNR) order. There’s also a note that family must be involved in any escalation decisions. Her daughter and son are on their way to the hospital now.
[ED NURSE]: Thanks. Any IV access?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: No IV inserted yet. She may need one for imaging or fluids depending on your assessment.
[ED NURSE]:  We’ll get her triaged and notify the medical team. I’ll also make sure we have written communication tools available for her.
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Perfect. She’s currently calm but may need reassurance once she’s in the bay.

example.text:
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Good morning, Mr. Carter. I’m Dr. Chen from City Thoracic Unit. I’ll just get the handover from my colleague now, if that’s alright.
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: This should be Bed 5, James Carter, 62 years old, under Dr. Singh — I believe he’s the thoracic surgeon on today’s roster. Mr. Carter was admitted yesterday after referral from oncology for surgical review of what appears to be a left upper lobe non-small cell lung carcinoma. He’s had increasing shortness of breath and fatigue over the past month — he’s not sure exactly when it started worsening. CT chest shows a 3.8 cm lesion with no definite mediastinal involvement, but margins are still being reviewed. The PET from last week shows localized uptake, though I think pathology hasn’t correlated all the findings yet.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: He’s currently haemodynamically stable. No haemoptysis or chest pain reported overnight. Oxygen sats are sitting around 96% on room air. Pain’s been manageable with regular paracetamol. No major changes overnight, though he mentioned feeling “a bit tighter” this morning.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Hi Mr. Carter, can I just confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: James Carter.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Great, and I’ll check your wristband… that matches. Are you having any pain or discomfort at the moment?
[PATIENT]: Just some chest tightness, not bad though.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: Vitals this morning roughly BP 132/78, HR 76, RR 18, Temp 36.9, SpO₂ 96%. I’ll double‑check the printed obs to be sure.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Any allergies?
[PATIENT]: No known allergies.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Okay, I’ll confirm that in the chart. What about current medications?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: He’s on regular paracetamol one gram QID, salbutamol inhaler as needed, pantoprazole 40 daily. No antibiotics at present — there was some discussion yesterday about prophylaxis, but decision pending surgical review. IV fluids were stopped overnight; he’s nil by mouth while waiting for the team to confirm theatre timing, which I think will depend on bed availability and the PFT results.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Any relevant medical history?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: Yes — hypertension controlled on amlodipine 5 mg daily, former smoker, about a 30‑pack‑year history, no diabetes that I know of, and no previous thoracic surgery. Oncology mentioned possible mild COPD features, but that hasn’t been formally diagnosed.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: So, plan is MDT review today for potential lobectomy or segmentectomy, is that right?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: Yes, that’s the plan as far as I know. Pulmonary function tests are pending — I think they were booked for this morning, but not entirely sure if they’ve been collected yet. Bloods from yesterday were within normal limits — WCC 7.8, CRP 12, renal and liver fine, ECG normal sinus rhythm. No other outstanding investigations I’m aware of.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Great, thanks. Mr. Carter, anything you need before we wrap up?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Just waiting to find out what’s happening with surgery.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Perfect. We’ll review your results and let you know once the MDT discussion’s finished — should be sometime later today, depending on when the list starts.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mr. Reynolds is Day 1 post-op from an aortic valve replacement. He returned from theatre yesterday afternoon and was transferred to the cardiac surgical ward overnight. He’s currently on telemetry monitoring. Vitals have remained stable. He’s receiving supplemental oxygen via nasal prongs at 2L/min.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pain is being managed with PCA (fentanyl), and he’s tolerating sips of water. Chest drain output overnight was 120 mL serosanguinous, within expected range. No signs of bleeding or infection. He’s been assisted to sit up in bed with physiotherapy this morning.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Reynolds, how are you feeling this morning? Any pain or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: A bit sore, but I’m okay. Just tired.

[PATIENT]: No, I’m fine for now.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and review your chart, Mr. Reynolds.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Ms. Evans. I’m Sarah, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Evans. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Chloe Evans.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Chloe Evans in Bed 2, Room 10, aged 24, under Dr. Langford, Psychiatry Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Evans was admitted via ED yesterday with concerns of severe restrictive eating behaviour, low BMI, and fatigue. She was brought in by her mother, who reported significant weight loss over the past 3 months and increasing social withdrawal.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s currently on fluid and nutritional monitoring and has been started on a re-feeding protocol under dietitian guidance. Bloods show mild electrolyte imbalance—low phosphate and potassium. ECG showed sinus bradycardia, which is being monitored.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s alert and cooperative but has expressed anxiety around food and body image. A social worker referral has been made to support family involvement and explore outpatient supports post-discharge.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ms. Evans, how are you feeling this morning? Any dizziness or nausea?
[PATIENT]: Just a bit light-headed, but I’m okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s had sips of oral nutrition supplement this morning and tolerated it. No vomiting or diarrhoea. Vitals are stable but she remains on daily ECG and bloods. She’s aware of the care plan and has agreed to meet with the mental health team later today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up with the dietitian and social worker and let the team know when your bloods are back. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and review your chart, Ms. Evans.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Emily. I’m Sarah, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Emily. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Emily Dawson.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Emily Dawson, 16 years old, in Bed 3, Room 12, under Dr. Langford, Adolescent Mental Health Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Emily was admitted yesterday via ED with concerns of restrictive eating, rapid weight loss, and fatigue. She was referred by her GP and brought in by her parents, who report increasing anxiety around food and body image.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s currently on a nutritional refeeding protocol and fluid balance charting. Bloods show low phosphate, mild hypokalaemia, and bradycardia on ECG. She’s on daily bloods and ECG monitoring. Dietitian and adolescent psychiatrist have reviewed her this morning.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Emily is alert and cooperative but has expressed distress around meals. She’s had half a supplement drink this morning and tolerated it. No vomiting or laxative use reported. She’s been resting in bed and has not yet mobilised.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Emily, how are you feeling this morning? Any dizziness or nausea?
[PATIENT]: Just a bit tired. I don’t really want to eat.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s aware of the care plan and has agreed to meet with the social worker and psychologist later today. Her parents are involved and have asked for regular updates. No known allergies. No regular medications.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up with the mental health team and dietitian and let the team know when your bloods are back. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and review your chart, Emily.

example.text:
[PARAMEDIC]: Hi, this is John, paramedic with Metro Ambulance. We’ve brought in Ms. Helen Morris, aged 72, from home. She’s currently in Bed 6, Isolation Bay 2.
[PARAMEDIC]: Ms. Morris was referred by her GP due to increasing shortness of breath, productive cough, and low-grade fever over the past 3 days. Her GP suspected RSV due to recent community cases and her history of COPD. She lives with her husband, who is currently well.
[PARAMEDIC]: On arrival, she was SpO? 91% on room air, now on 2L nasal prongs, saturating at 95%. RR 22, HR 88, BP 138/82, Temp 37.8°C. She’s alert and oriented but fatigued.
[PARAMEDIC]: We’ve placed her in isolation as a precaution. Full PPE is being used. She’s been cooperative and understands the need for precautions. No known allergies. Regular medications include tiotropium, salbutamol, and amlodipine.
[PARAMEDIC]: No recent hospital admissions. She’s had two doses of COVID vaccine and annual flu shot. No RSV test done yet—GP advised swab on arrival.
[PARAMEDIC]: She’s stable for now. No chest pain or confusion. Handover complete—do you have any questions?
[ED NURSE]: Thanks, John. I’ll get her settled and notify the medical team for review and swabbing. I’ll continue isolation precautions and monitor her respiratory status.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Jackson. I’m Sarah, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Jackson. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: David Jackson.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Mr. David Jackson in Bed 4, Room 6, aged 64, under Dr. Patel, Orthopaedic Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mr. Jackson was admitted two days ago following a left femoral neck fracture sustained at home. He’s awaiting ORIF surgery, which is scheduled for tomorrow morning. He had a fall in the bathroom overnight—he slipped while attempting to mobilise independently.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Post-fall assessment was completed. No new injuries noted. He was reviewed by the medical team and remains hemodynamically stable. Neurovascular status of the affected limb is unchanged. Observations have remained within normal limits.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pain is being managed with regular paracetamol and PRN oxycodone. Pain score was 5/10 on movement this morning. He’s currently on bed rest and has been reminded to use the call bell before mobilising. A falls incident report has been completed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Jackson, how are you feeling this morning? Any pain or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: Just sore in the hip, but no dizziness.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s tolerating oral intake and has no nausea. No signs of infection. Pre-op bloods and ECG have been completed. Consent for surgery is signed and documented. Physio will review post-op.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up with the surgical team and ensure falls precautions are in place. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and review your chart, Mr. Jackson.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Jackson. I’m Sarah, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Jackson. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: David Jackson.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Mr. David Jackson in Bed 4, Room 6, aged 64, under Dr. Patel, Orthopaedic Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mr. Jackson is awaiting ORIF surgery for a left femoral neck fracture, scheduled for tomorrow. He’s been stable overnight, but this morning he reported lower abdominal discomfort and has not passed urine since yesterday evening.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bladder scan showed retention of 650 mL. Medical team reviewed and requested an IDC insertion. He’s alert, cooperative, and understands the procedure. No known allergies. Pain is currently 3/10 on movement.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Jackson, I’ll be inserting a catheter shortly to help relieve the pressure in your bladder. I’ll explain everything before we begin.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you. It’s really uncomfortable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I understand. I’ll get everything ready now.
[SARAH]: Hey, Jess—sorry to interrupt. I’ve got a patient in Room 6 with urinary retention and needs an IDC. I haven’t done one before—would you mind assisting or supervising?
[JESS]: Of course, happy to help. Let’s grab the trolley and go through it together. I’ll walk you through the steps.
[SARAH]: Thanks so much. I’ve read the protocol, just haven’t had the chance to do one hands-on yet.
[JESS]: No worries—we’ll take it slow and make sure Mr. Jackson is comfortable throughout.
[NURSE SARAH]: Hi Mr. Jackson, I just wanted to check in. I understand you’re still feeling quite uncomfortable.
[PATIENT]: Yes, I still haven’t been able to pass urine. It’s getting worse.
[NURSE SARAH]: I’m sorry to hear that. We’ve done a bladder scan and it shows you’re retaining quite a bit—over 700 mL. The doctor will be coming shortly to insert a catheter to relieve the pressure.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you.
[NURSE SARAH]: Hi Dr. Patel, sorry to interrupt. Mr. Jackson in Room 6 has urinary retention—bladder scan shows 740 mL. I attempted an IDC but met resistance and he was quite uncomfortable. Would you be able to insert it?
[DR. PATEL]: Yes, I can do that. Can you get the trolley set up and let me know when it’s ready?
[NURSE SARAH]: Absolutely. I’ll prepare the sterile field now.
[NURSE SARAH]: Dr. Patel, the trolley is set up and Mr. Jackson has been informed. He’s ready when you are.
[DR. PATEL]: Great, let’s go ahead. Can you assist with maintaining the sterile field?
[NURSE SARAH]: Of course.

example.text:
[NURSE AMY]: Good morning, Ms. Carter. I’m Amy, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Carter. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Jessica Carter.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Jessica Carter in Bed 5, Room 11, aged 35, under Dr. Nguyen, Orthopaedic Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Carter was admitted yesterday following a fall at home. She has a displaced fracture of the right humerus and is scheduled for ORIF surgery tomorrow morning. She’s currently in a sling and on regular analgesia. Pain score was 6/10 earlier, now 3/10 after medication.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Neurovascular obs are intact: her Capillary refill <2 seconds, Sensation present, her Movement limited due to pain but preserved, there is No swelling or discoloration noted
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s a single mother of two young children and has expressed concern about managing at home post-op. A social worker referral has been made to explore home support and childcare options.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: Hi Jessica, I’m Priya from physio. I’ve reviewed your chart and will work with you post-op to help regain movement and strength in your arm. For now, just rest and keep the arm supported. After surgery, we’ll start gentle exercises and discuss strategies for managing daily tasks one-handed.
[PATIENT]: Okay, I’m worried about how I’ll manage with the kids.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: That’s understandable. We’ll work closely with the social worker and nursing team to make sure you have the right support in place.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Hi Jessica, I’m Mark from social work. I understand you’re concerned about managing at home after surgery. Can you tell me a bit about your current support system?
[PATIENT]: It’s just me and the kids. My mum lives interstate and I don’t have anyone nearby.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thanks for sharing. I’ll look into short-term home care options and community support services. We can also explore childcare assistance while you recover. I’ll keep you updated and help with any paperwork.
[NURSE AMY]: I’ll continue monitoring your pain and neurovascular status, and coordinate with the surgical team. Let me know if you need anything, Jessica.
[PATIENT]: Thank you. I really appreciate it.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 7, Mr. David Tran, 62 years old. He’s been admitted with non-small cell lung cancer affecting the left upper lobe. He’s scheduled for a left pneumonectomy tomorrow morning.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. What’s happening currently?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s stable at present. Pre-op workup is complete—he’s had a CT chest, PET scan, and pulmonary function tests. Anaesthetics and thoracics have reviewed him. He’s fasting from midnight and has been consented for surgery.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any symptoms or concerns?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s mildly anxious, understandably. No respiratory distress, oxygen saturations are 96% on room air. He’s been coughing occasionally but no haemoptysis. Pain is well controlled with regular paracetamol.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any comorbidities?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—hypertension and type 2 diabetes, both well-managed. He’s on metformin and amlodipine. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any communication or support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is his second language—Vietnamese is his first. He understands most conversations but prefers simple explanations. Interpreter has been booked for the surgical consent and post-op education. His wife is his next of kin and has been very involved.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other prep needed?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s had pre-op bloods, ECG, and group and hold done. TEDs are on, and he’s been educated on incentive spirometry. Surgical checklist is complete. Just needs pre-op IV fluids started at 6 am.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep an eye on his anxiety and ensure he’s ready for theatre.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything changes overnight. All documentation is up to date.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]:
Hi, I’m heading off for my break now. Can I hand over Mrs. Margaret Ellis in bed 3 to you?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Sure, go ahead.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s 87, came in from Rosewood Nursing Home after a fall with head strike. There’s a small occipital hematoma, no loss of consciousness reported, but she’s been drowsy and mildly confused. Vitals are stable. GCS is 14.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Any advanced care planning?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she has a DNR order from the nursing home. Family is aware and on their way in—we’re waiting for them before making any escalation decisions.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she’s deaf. No hearing aids with her today. She responds best to written notes and gestures. I’ve left a whiteboard and marker at the bedside.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Anything else I should know?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she’s just been found incontinent of urine. She needs to be cleaned up—I’ve gathered the continence supplies but haven’t had a chance to assist her yet. She’s calm and cooperative.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: No worries, I’ll take care of that now.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything changes. I’ll be back in 30 minutes.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’M Brad am I’m handing over bed 12, Mrs. Maria Giannopoulos, 81 years old. She’s been admitted for severe symptomatic aortic stenosis and is scheduled for a TAVI tomorrow morning.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. What’s happening currently?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s stable. No chest pain or syncope overnight. She’s NYHA Class III—gets breathless on minimal exertion. Vitals are within normal limits, and she’s on telemetry. No arrhythmias noted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Has she been reviewed by the team?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, cardiology and interventional have reviewed. She’s been consented, and the procedure is booked for 8:00 AM. She’s fasting from midnight. Pre-op checklist is complete.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any comorbidities?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—hypertension, chronic kidney disease stage 3, and mild cognitive impairment. She’s on perindopril, frusemide, and aspirin. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is her second language—Greek is her first. She understands most things but prefers slow, clear explanations. Interpreter has been arranged for the morning. Her son is her substitute decision-maker and has been involved in all discussions.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any concerns overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She was a bit anxious about the procedure but settled after reassurance. No acute issues. She’s continent, mobilising with assistance, and on a low-sodium diet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep her calm and prep her for theatre in the morning.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything changes. All documentation is up to date, including the consent and pre-op orders.

example.text:
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: Hi, I'm handing over bed 9, Mr. Jamal Khan, 28 years old. He’s presented to ED with diabetic ketoacidosis. He has type 1 diabetes, diagnosed at age 14.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Thanks. What brought him in?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: He’s had three days of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. He stopped taking insulin due to poor oral intake. He was tachypnoeic and dehydrated on arrival. Capillary ketones were 6.8, BGL was 28.4, and venous pH was 7.12.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: What’s been done so far?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: He’s been managed as per the DKA protocol—IV fluids, fixed-rate insulin infusion, and hourly BGL and ketone monitoring. Electrolytes are being replaced as needed. He’s improving—ketones are now 2.4, and pH is 7.28. Still on insulin infusion.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Any complications?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: No cerebral oedema or arrhythmias. He’s alert and oriented, tolerating sips of water. No vomiting since arrival. Vitals are stable—HR 92, BP 118/72, RR 20, SpO? 98% on room air.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Any comorbidities or allergies?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: No other medical history. No known drug allergies. He’s usually on basal-bolus insulin at home—Lantus and Novorapid.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Any social or communication needs?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: English is his first language. Lives alone, works full-time. He’s anxious about being admitted but cooperative. Diabetes educator has been flagged for review tomorrow.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Got it. I’ll continue monitoring his BGLs, ketones, and electrolytes, and keep him on protocol.
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if he deteriorates or if there are any concerns with fluid balance. All documentation is up to date, including fluid balance chart and DKA pathway.

example.text:
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: Hi, i'm handing over bed 4, Ms. Aisha Patel, 34 years old. She’s presented to ED with acute gastroenteritis—onset was about 24 hours ago.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Thanks. What are her main symptoms?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: Profuse watery diarrhoea—about 6 episodes in the last 12 hours—and 3 episodes of vomiting. No blood in stool. She’s had mild abdominal cramping and reports feeling dizzy when standing.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: What’s been done in ED?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: She’s been rehydrated with 2 litres of IV normal saline. Bloods were taken—U&Es show mild hypokalaemia, which we’ve started correcting. Stool sample has been sent. She’s afebrile, and vitals are now stable—BP 108/70, HR 92, afebrile, RR 18, SpO? 99% on room air.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Any medications?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: Ondansetron 4 mg IV given with good effect. She’s tolerating sips of water now. No antibiotics charted at this stage—awaiting stool results. Electrolyte replacement is charted.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Any comorbidities or allergies?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: No known medical history. No regular medications. NKDA.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Any communication or social needs?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: English is her first language. Lives alone, works as a teacher. She’s a bit embarrassed about the symptoms but otherwise coping well. Prefers a female nurse if possible.
[INCOMING WAR DNURSE]: Got it. I’ll continue fluids, monitor output, and keep an eye on her electrolytes.
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if she deteriorates or becomes febrile. All documentation is up to date, including fluid balance and stool chart.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi,i'm handing over bed 6, Mr. Robert Mason, 76 years old. He’s in with an acute exacerbation of congestive cardiac failure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, what’s his current status?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s still a bit fluid overloaded—short of breath on minimal exertion and needing 2 L of oxygen to keep sats above 92%. He’s had IV frusemide 40 mg this morning and passed about 600 mL. Chest sounds are crackly bilaterally.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How are his obs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Vitals are stable—BP 110/68, HR 88, afebrile, RR 20. He’s alert and oriented, but a bit anxious. No chest pain reported.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any background?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—he has ischaemic cardiomyopathy with an EF of 30%. Also has type 2 diabetes and CKD stage 3. Usual meds include carvedilol, perindopril, spironolactone, and frusemide. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How’s his fluid balance?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Positive overnight but trending down. He’s on strict fluid balance and daily weights. We’ve started a fluid restriction—1.5 L per 24 hours.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is his first language. His wife is his main support and has been in today. He’s a bit anxious about his breathing but very cooperative.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll continue monitoring his fluid status and oxygen needs.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if his respiratory status worsens or if he doesn’t respond to diuresis. All documentation is up to date, including fluid balance and med chart.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I'm handing over bed 11, Mr. Thomas Nguyen, 64 years old. He’s been admitted with multiple left-sided rib fractures—ribs 5 through 8—after a fall from a ladder yesterday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ouch. How’s he doing now?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s stable but in quite a bit of pain, especially with deep breathing and movement. He’s on regular paracetamol and oxycodone PRN. We’ve also started a fentanyl PCA overnight, which he’s using appropriately.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any respiratory concerns?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No signs of pneumothorax or haemothorax on imaging. Chest X-ray shows isolated rib fractures. He’s on 2 L nasal prongs to maintain sats above 94%. We’re encouraging deep breathing and coughing—he’s using the incentive spirometer.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any comorbidities?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hypertension and mild COPD. No known allergies. He’s a non-smoker now but has a 30-pack-year history.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mobilising?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: With assistance. Physio reviewed this morning and will continue daily. He’s slow but safe with a frame. Needs supervision for toileting.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any communication or support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is his first language. Lives with his wife. He’s a bit frustrated with the pain but very cooperative.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep an eye on his pain and respiratory effort.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if his pain escalates or if there are any signs of respiratory compromise. All documentation is up to date, including pain scores and PCA charting.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I'm John, handing over bed 2, Ms. Leila Haddad, 59 years old. She’s been admitted with a large pericardial effusion—likely secondary to metastatic breast cancer. She’s for pericardiocentesis this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. How is she currently?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s haemodynamically stable but symptomatic—short of breath at rest, mild chest tightness, and fatigue. No syncope or hypotension. She’s on 2 L nasal prongs to maintain sats around 94%.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s been done so far?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s had an urgent echo showing a large effusion with early signs of tamponade. Cardiology has reviewed and booked her for ultrasound-guided pericardiocentesis this afternoon. Consent is done.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Two good IVs—one 18G in the left AC and a 20G in the right forearm. Both patent. She’s on maintenance IV fluids—normal saline at 75 mL/hr.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s had IV dexamethasone 8 mg this morning and regular paracetamol for discomfort. PRN midazolam is charted for the procedure. No anticoagulants on board. NKDA.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Observations?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: BP 102/68, HR 98, RR 22, SpO? 94% on 2 L, Temp 36.8. She’s alert and oriented but anxious. ECG shows low voltage QRS, no arrhythmias.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is her second language—Arabic is her first. She understands most things but prefers slow explanations. Her daughter is bilingual and has been helping. Interpreter has been requested for post-procedure education.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep monitoring her obs closely and prep her for the drain.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if she deteriorates—especially signs of tamponade like hypotension or muffled heart sounds. All documentation is up to date, including consent, obs, and fluid balance.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 8, Mr. Angelo Romano, 84 years old. He’s in for a TAVI via left subclavian access, scheduled for tomorrow morning. He’s now developed a new arrhythmia—I’ve notified the medical team.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay—what kind of arrhythmia?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He went into new-onset atrial fibrillation about an hour ago—irregularly irregular rhythm, HR peaked at 130. He’s asymptomatic but more confused than usual. No chest pain or syncope. ECG has been done and uploaded.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s been done so far?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The cardiology registrar has been notified and is reviewing. We’ve done a full set of bloods including U&Es, magnesium, and troponin. He’s on telemetry and we’re monitoring closely. No rate control started yet—awaiting medical orders.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s his baseline?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Normally in sinus rhythm. He’s got known aortic stenosis and mild cognitive impairment. He’s also incontinent of urine—currently in pads. No IDC.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Two good IVs—18G in the right forearm and 20G in the left hand. Maintenance fluids running at 75 mL/hr. He’s fasting from midnight for the procedure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Regular meds include frusemide, aspirin, and atorvastatin. No anticoagulants yet—this will likely be reviewed post-TAVI. PRN paracetamol and haloperidol are charted. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any support needs?

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 5, Ms. Carol Tan, 72 years old. She was admitted for a permanent pacemaker insertion due to symptomatic bradycardia. The procedure was done this morning, but she’s developed a left-sided pneumothorax post-op.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Oh no—how was it picked up?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She became short of breath and desaturated to 89% on room air about an hour post-procedure. Chest X-ray confirmed a moderate pneumothorax. The cardiology team has reviewed, and a chest drain has been inserted—left side, mid-axillary line.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How is she now?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: More comfortable. She’s on 2 L nasal prongs—sats are now 96%. Drain is on low suction and swinging well. No signs of tension. Vitals are stable—BP 122/70, HR 78 (paced), RR 20, Temp 36.7.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: One 20G in the right forearm—patent. She’s on maintenance IV fluids—normal saline at 75 mL/hr. No IV antibiotics charted at this stage.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Regular meds include metoprolol, atorvastatin, and aspirin. She’s had paracetamol for mild post-op pain. No known allergies. Analgesia and PRNs are charted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other concerns?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s a bit anxious and tearful—understandably shaken by the complication. English is her first language. She’s continent and mobilising with assistance. Physio has been informed for post-drain mobility review.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll monitor the drain, pain, and oxygen needs closely.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let the team know if there’s any increase in respiratory distress or if the drain output changes significantly. All documentation is up to date, including drain chart, obs, and post-op notes.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 10, this is Mrs. Joan Murphy, 73 years old. Joan, this is Nurse Alex, who’ll be looking after you this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Joan, nice to meet you. I’ll be taking over your care now. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: Still a bit breathless, but better than this morning.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Joan came in overnight with an acute exacerbation of COPD—increased shortness of breath, wheeze, and productive cough. She’s now on IV ceftriaxone and IV hydrocortisone, both charted for 3 days. She’s also on salbutamol and ipratropium nebs Q4H.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. What’s her oxygen requirement?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on 2 L via nasal prongs to keep sats between 88–92%—that’s her target range. She desats quickly if off oxygen. Her Q-ADDS score was 4 earlier due to increased RR and oxygen requirement, so she’s on 2-hourly observations.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any recent changes?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s improving slowly. RR is down to 22, sats 91% on 2 L, HR 96, BP 134/78, Temp 37.4. She’s afebrile now. We’ve started a fluid balance chart—she’s on IV fluids at 75 mL/hr due to poor oral intake. Strict input/output is being monitored.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any comorbidities?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—hypertension and osteoporosis. No known drug allergies. She’s normally independent at home but has needed assistance with ADLs today due to fatigue.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Joan, are you managing okay with meals and drinks?
[PATIENT]: Not really hungry, but I’ve had some soup and water.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: That’s okay—we’ll keep encouraging fluids and monitor your intake.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s also on a respiratory chart—we’re tracking sputum colour, volume, and work of breathing. Physio has been to see her and will review again tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Joan, I’ll check your obs shortly and make sure your breathing stays comfortable. Let me know if you feel more breathless or unwell.
[PATIENT]: Will do. Thank you both.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All documentation is up to date—Q-ADDS, fluid balance, and respiratory charting. Let the team know if her Q-ADDS score increases or if she deteriorates.

example.text:
[WARD_NURSE]: Hi, thanks for coming to see Mr. Alan Brooks in bed 12. He’s Day 1 post-CABG, just transferred from ICU this morning. He’s stable but still has several attachments in place, so we’ll need to be cautious with mobility.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: Can you give me a quick overview?
[WARD_NURSE]: Sure. He had a triple vessel CABG yesterday. He’s currently on: IV dopamine, weaning at 0.05 mcg/kg/min, currently running at 3 mcg/min, he has a CVL in the right internal jugular, there are Three chest drains still in situ. He has an IDC draining clear urine, Telemetry monitoring active. 
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: Okay. Is he alert and able to follow instructions?
[WARD_NURSE]: Yes, he’s alert, orientated, and cooperative. Pain is well-managed with paracetamol and PRN oxycodone. He’s keen to mobilise but understandably anxious.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: Any precautions I should be aware of?
[WARD_NURSE]: Yes—sternal precautions apply. No pushing or pulling with arms, no lifting above shoulder height. We’ll need to support the chest drains and CVL during movement. IDC can be secured to the leg.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: Any recent obs or concerns?
[WARD_NURSE]:
Vitals are stable: BP: 104/68, HR: 88 bpm, sinus rhythm, SpO?: 96% on room air
No dizziness or desaturation noted. He’s due for obs in 30 minutes.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: I’ll start with a gentle sit-out and breathing exercises and reassess tolerance. I’ll liaise with the team about progressing mobility tomorrow.
[WARD_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if you need help with attachments or if anything changes.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 3, Mr. David Lee, 79 years old. He had a permanent pacemaker inserted this morning for complete heart block. Post-procedure, he developed a right-sided pneumothorax—a chest drain was inserted about an hour ago.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay—how is he now?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s more short of breath and becoming increasingly agitated. His oxygen requirement has gone up—now on 4 L via nasal prongs to maintain sats around 92%. BP is 98/60, HR is 62 (paced), RR 26, Temp 37.2. I’ve escalated to the medical registrar—awaiting review.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How’s the drain functioning?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Swinging but minimal drainage so far. No signs of tension, but I’m concerned about his increased work of breathing and agitation. ECG shows paced rhythm, no acute changes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other issues?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—he’s acutely incontinent of urine and hasn’t voided since the procedure. Abdomen is mildly distended. I’ve requested an IDC insertion—awaiting medical clearance due to the recent pacing procedure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: One 18G in the left forearm—patent. He’s on maintenance fluids and has had IV paracetamol for discomfort. No antibiotics charted yet. NKDA.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is his first language. He’s usually independent but is now confused and distressed. Family has been notified and are on their way in.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep monitoring his respiratory status and follow up on the IDC and medical review.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. Please escalate if his condition worsens—especially if his sats drop further or he becomes more confused. All documentation is up to date, including drain chart, fluid balance, and neuro obs.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I'm  handing over bed 14, this is Ms. Emily Dawson, 67 years old. Emily, this is Nurse Priya, who’ll be looking after you this evening.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Emily, nice to meet you. I’ll be taking over your care now. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: A bit sore, but okay. Just tired.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Emily came in this morning after a fall at home—she tripped over a rug and landed on her outstretched left arm. X-rays confirmed a closed fracture of the left distal radius. It’s been immobilised in a backslab, and ortho has reviewed—she’s for conservative management at this stage.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. Any pain relief?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—she’s had regular paracetamol and one dose of oxycodone 5 mg earlier this afternoon. Pain is currently 3 out of 10, and she’s tolerating it well. PRNs are charted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No IV needed—she’s on oral meds only. Vitals have been stable all shift—BP 132/76, HR 78, afebrile, SpO? 98% on room air.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Emily, are you managing okay with eating, drinking, and getting around?
[PATIENT]: Yes, I can manage with my right hand. I just need help getting to the bathroom.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s mobilising with supervision. No dizziness or unsteadiness, but we’ve kept her on assisted walks just in case. OT and physio have been referred for tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any allergies or other medical issues?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No known drug allergies. Medical history includes hypertension and osteoarthritis. She’s on amlodipine and takes Panadol Osteo regularly at home.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Emily, I’ll check in on your pain and help you settle in for the evening. If you need anything, just press the call bell.
[PATIENT]: Thank you both. I appreciate it.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All documentation is up to date, including neurovascular checks and pain scores. Let me know if anything changes.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi, this is Mrs. Joan Murphy, 73 years old. Joan, this is Liam, one of our physiotherapists. He’s here to help with your breathing and to assist with collecting a sputum sample.
[PHYSIO]: Hi Joan, nice to meet you. I’ll be working with you today to help clear your chest and get a sample if we can. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: Still a bit chesty and tired. I’ve been coughing but not bringing much up.
[NURSE]: Joan came in last night with an acute exacerbation of COPD—increased SOB, wheeze, and a productive cough. She’s now on IV ceftriaxone and hydrocortisone, and we’re trying to get a sputum sample for culture before the next dose.
[PHYSIO]: Okay, has she been able to expectorate anything yet?
[NURSE]: Not yet—she’s coughing but not clearing much. She’s on salbutamol and ipratropium nebs Q4H, and we’ve just given her a neb about 20 minutes ago to help loosen things up.
[PHYSIO]: Great, that should help. I’ll do some chest physio and see if we can get a sample.
[NURSE]: She’s on 2 L nasal prongs, target sats 88–92%. Her Q-ADDS score is 4, so she’s on 2-hourly observations. RR is 22, sats 91%, HR 96, BP 134/78, Temp 37.4. She’s also on a respiratory chart—we’re tracking sputum colour and volume, and she’s on a fluid balance chart due to poor oral intake.
[PHYSIO]: Understood. Joan, I’ll help you with some breathing techniques and gentle percussion. If you feel the urge to cough anything up, we’ll collect it in a sterile pot.
[PATIENT]: Okay, I’ll try.
[NURSE]: Thanks, Liam. Let me know if you’re able to get a sample or if she needs a second neb beforehand. Everything’s documented in the chart, and the pathology slip is ready.

example.text:
[WARD NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Peter Samuels, 69 years old. He’s being transferred to CCU with acute decompensated heart failure. Peter, this is Nurse Jess from the coronary care unit, and Dr. Patel, who’s overseeing your care.
[CCU NURSE]: Hi Peter, I’ll be looking after you in CCU. We’ll get you settled in and keep a close eye on your breathing and heart.
[PATIENT]: Thank you. I’m still feeling short of breath.
[WARD NURSE]: He came in yesterday with worsening dyspnoea, orthopnoea, and peripheral oedema. Chest X-ray showed pulmonary congestion. He’s been started on IV frusemide 40 mg BD, and a GTN infusion was commenced this morning for ongoing hypertension and chest tightness.
[DOCTOR]: We’re titrating the GTN to manage his preload and afterload. He’s also on oxygen via nasal prongs at 4 L/min, aiming for sats above 92%. We’ll review the need for non-invasive ventilation if he doesn’t improve.
[CCU NURSE]: What’s his current status?
[WARD NURSE]: He’s still dyspnoeic at rest. Q-ADDS score is 6—due to increased RR (28), borderline BP (98/60), and oxygen requirement. He’s on hourly observations. HR is 104, Temp 36.8, SpO? 93% on 4 L.
[CCU NURSE]: IV access?
[WARD NURSE]: Two good IVs—18G in the right AC and 20G in the left forearm. GTN is running via pump on the right side. He’s also on a strict fluid balance chart—he’s positive 1.2 L over the last 24 hours. Daily weights are being recorded.
[CCU NURSE]: Any other meds or comorbidities?
[WARD NURSE]: He’s on carvedilol, spironolactone, and atorvastatin. No known allergies. History of ischaemic cardiomyopathy, EF 25%, and CKD stage 3.
[PATIENT]: I’ve been feeling more tired and dizzy today.
[DOCTOR]: That’s why we’re moving you to CCU, Peter—to monitor you more closely and adjust your treatment as needed.
[CCU NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll continue hourly Q-ADDS, monitor the GTN infusion, and keep a close eye on his fluid status and oxygen needs.
[WARD NURSE]: Perfect. All documentation is up to date—Q-ADDS, fluid balance, and medication chart. Let me know if you need anything else.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Ms. Lily Harper, 24 years old. Lily, this is Nurse Tessa, who’ll be looking after you this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Lily, nice to meet you. I’ll be checking in on you regularly and helping with your care today.
[PATIENT]: Hi. Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Lily was admitted yesterday with bradycardia secondary to an eating disorder—her HR dropped to 38 bpm overnight. She’s now in CCU for cardiac monitoring. She’s alert and oriented but fatigued and intermittently dizzy.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s her current status?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: HR is sitting around 42–45 bpm, sinus bradycardia on telemetry. BP is 92/58, RR 16, SpO? 98% on room air, Temp 36.2. She’s on Q-ADDS—scoring 5 due to HR and low-normal BP, so we’re doing hourly observations.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—20G in the left forearm, patent. No IV fluids running currently, but we’ve kept the line in for access if needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on thiamine and multivitamins orally, and PRN lorazepam for anxiety. No cardiac meds charted at this stage. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How’s her intake?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We’ve started a strict food and fluid chart. Dietitian has reviewed and started a re-feeding plan—small, frequent meals. She’s eating slowly but has managed about 50% of her breakfast and lunch today. We’re monitoring for refeeding syndrome—daily bloods are being done.
[PATIENT]: I’m trying to eat, but it’s hard.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: That’s okay, Lily. We’ll support you through it. Just let me know if you feel unwell or overwhelmed.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s also on daily ECGs and electrolyte monitoring. Psych team has been consulted and will review again tomorrow. She’s been cooperative but very anxious.
[DOCTOR]: (enters briefly) Just confirming—Lily is for continued cardiac monitoring and nutritional support. Please escalate if HR drops below 35 or if she becomes symptomatic.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll continue Q-ADDS, monitor intake, and keep an eye on her cardiac rhythm and electrolytes.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. All documentation is up to date—Q-ADDS, food chart, and med chart.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. James Daniels, 58 years old. James, this is Nurse Sarah, who’ll be looking after you this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi James, I’ll be your nurse for the next shift. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: Bloated and uncomfortable. It’s hard to breathe when I lie flat.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: James has decompensated liver disease from long-term alcohol use. He’s been admitted with tense ascites—his abdomen is distended and uncomfortable, and he’s short of breath. He’s for a therapeutic paracentesis this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Has he been consented?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, the medical team has reviewed and consented him. Ultrasound has confirmed large-volume ascites. He’s been fasted, and we’ve inserted a 20G IV in the right forearm—patent and flushed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on IV albumin post-drain as per protocol, and oral spironolactone and frusemide. No antibiotics charted yet—awaiting fluid culture results. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Fluid balance?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a strict fluid balance chart. We’ve started daily weights and abdominal girth measurements. He’s mildly hypotensive—BP 94/60, HR 88, RR 20, SpO? 96% on room air. Temp 36.9. He’s on Q-ADDS—scoring 3 due to low BP, so we’re doing 4-hourly observations.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is his first language. He’s alert and oriented but anxious about the procedure. He’s been open about his alcohol use and is willing to engage with support services. Social work and AOD team have been referred.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. James, I’ll check your obs and help you get comfortable before the procedure. Let me know if you feel dizzy or more bloated.
[PATIENT]: Thanks. I just want this fluid out.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All documentation is up to date—fluid chart, Q-ADDS, and med chart. Let the team know if his BP drops further or if there are signs of infection post-drain.

example.text:
[NIGHT_NURSE]: Morning. Handing over Mrs. Evelyn Taylor, 81 years old, in bed 7. Evelyn, this is Nurse Mia, who’ll be looking after you today.
[MORNING_NURSE]: Hi Evelyn, I’ll be your nurse this morning. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: I feel a bit strange. My right arm feels heavy, and I’m having trouble speaking clearly.
[NIGHT_NURSE]: That’s actually new. She was drowsy overnight, but I thought it was just fatigue. I didn’t notice any clear deficits during the night, but she’s now showing slurred speech and right-sided weakness. I’ve just done a quick neuro check—there’s a facial droop and reduced grip on the right.
[MORNING_NURSE]: That sounds like a possible stroke. Has the doctor been notified?
[NIGHT_NURSE]: Not yet—I picked it up just before handover. I was about to escalate. She’s on Q-ADDS, scoring 6 now—due to new neuro changes and slightly elevated BP (162/94). HR 84, RR 18, SpO? 97% on room air, Temp 36.6.
[MORNING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll call the medical registrar immediately and start hourly neuro obs.
[DOCTOR]: (enters) I’ve just been informed. Evelyn, I’m Dr. Singh. We’re concerned you may have had a stroke overnight, and we’re going to do some urgent tests, including a CT scan.
[PATIENT]: Oh… I didn’t realise. I just thought I was tired.
[DOCTOR]: You did the right thing by speaking up. We’ll take care of you.
[MORNING_NURSE]: I’ll stay with her and start the neuro obs now. Is she nil by mouth?
[DOCTOR]: Yes, keep her NPO until we assess her swallow. I’ll organise an urgent stroke team review.
[NIGHT_NURSE]: She’s on a fluid balance chart, and her oral intake was minimal overnight. No IV fluids running yet. She’s on regular antihypertensives and aspirin. No known allergies.
[MORNING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll update the family once we have a clearer picture.
[NIGHT_NURSE]: Thanks. All documentation is up to date—Q-ADDS, med chart, and fluid balance.

pred_spans.label: SITUATION

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Daniel Jordan, 31 years old. Daniel, this is Alicia, one of our pharmacists. She’s here to talk to you about your new medication.
[PHARMACIST]: Hi Daniel, nice to meet you. I understand you’ve just been diagnosed with epilepsy.
[PATIENT]: Yeah… it’s a bit of a shock. I had a seizure yesterday, and they said it was my first one.
[NURSE]: He had a generalised tonic-clonic seizure yesterday morning. CT and EEG are pending, but neurology has started him on levetiracetam 500 mg BD. No IV access now—he’s on oral meds only. No known allergies.
[PHARMACIST]: Thanks. Daniel, I’ll go through how to take your medication, what side effects to watch for, and how to manage your day-to-day safely. Have you had a chance to read the medication leaflet?
[PATIENT]: Not yet. I’m still trying to take it all in.
[PHARMACIST]: That’s okay—we’ll take it step by step. Levetiracetam is taken twice a day, about 12 hours apart. It’s important not to miss doses. Some people feel a bit tired or moody when they first start, but that usually settles. If you feel very low or notice any big changes in mood, let us know straight away.
[NURSE]: He’s also on a food and fluid chart while we monitor his intake—he’s been a bit nauseous since yesterday but is improving.
[PHARMACIST]: Good to know. Daniel, you’ll also need to avoid driving for now—by law, you need to be seizure-free for a certain period before you can drive again. We’ll give you written information about that too.
[PATIENT]: Okay. I didn’t realise that.
[PHARMACIST]: Totally understandable. I’ll leave you with a medication info sheet and come back later to check if you have any questions. We’ll also make sure your GP and community pharmacy are updated when you’re discharged.
[NURSE]: Thanks, Alicia. I’ll keep monitoring his neuro obs and ensure he’s tolerating the meds. Daniel, just press the call bell if you feel unwell or have any questions.
[PATIENT]: Thanks both. I appreciate it.

example.text:
[ED NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Anna Lewis, 35 years old, being transferred to the surgical ward. Anna, this is Nurse Claire, who’ll be looking after you now. Mark, you’re welcome to stay with her as long as you need.
[WARD NURSE]: Hi Anna, hi Mark. I’m really sorry you’re going through this. I’ll do everything I can to make you comfortable and supported.
[PATIENT]: Thank you. I’m still trying to process everything.
[ED NURSE]: Anna presented to ED overnight with vaginal bleeding and cramping at 10 weeks gestation. An ultrasound confirmed no fetal heartbeat. She’s been reviewed by O&G and is for a D&C later today.
[WARD NURSE]: I’m so sorry, Anna. We’ll make sure you’re cared for gently. Have you had anything to eat or drink?
[PATIENT]: No, I haven’t eaten since yesterday evening.
[ED NURSE]: She’s been kept Nil by mouth since 2:00 AM. Vitals are stable—BP 110/70, HR 84, afebrile. She’s had paracetamol and a single dose of IV fluids. No allergies. She has a 20G IV in the left forearm, patent and flushed.
[WARD NURSE]: Any medications charted?
[ED NURSE]: Just analgesia and PRNs. No antibiotics yet. She’s on a fluid balance chart, and we’ve started Q-ADDS—currently scoring 1. She’s understandably tearful but oriented and engaging.
[DOCTOR]: (enters) Anna, I’m Dr. Nguyen from the surgical team. I’m very sorry for your loss. We’ll be performing a D&C this afternoon to help manage the bleeding and support your recovery. We’ll talk you through everything and answer any questions.
[PATIENT]: Will I be asleep for it?
[DOCTOR]: Yes, you’ll be under a light general anaesthetic. It’s a short procedure, and we’ll monitor you closely afterward.
[HUSBAND]: Can I stay with her until she goes to theatre?
[WARD NURSE]: Absolutely. We’ll make sure you’re both supported. I’ll also check in with the social worker and pastoral care team if you’d like someone to talk to.
[ED NURSE]: All documentation is up to date—fluid chart, Q-ADDS, and consent form. Please let the team know if her bleeding increases or if she becomes more distressed.

example.text:
[WARD NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Evelyn Grant, 87 years old, being transferred to the transit lounge to await transport back to her nursing home. Evelyn, this is Nurse Tom, who’ll be looking after you until your transport arrives.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Hi Evelyn, lovely to meet you. We’ll make sure you’re comfortable while you wait.
[WARD NURSE]: Evelyn was admitted five days ago with aspiration pneumonia. She’s responded well to IV antibiotics and supportive care. She’s now afebrile, respiratory rate is 18, SpO? 96% on room air, and she’s mobilising short distances with assistance.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Great. Any swallowing concerns?
[WARD NURSE]: Yes, she has known dysphagia—thickened fluids and minced moist diet. She’s been reviewed by speech pathology and is safe to resume her usual nursing home diet plan. No signs of aspiration since admission.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Okay. Any medications due?
[WARD NURSE]: No meds due during transit. She’s had her morning meds—oral antibiotics completed yesterday. No allergies. She has a 22G IV in the left hand, but it can be removed before discharge.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Any behavioural concerns?
[WARD NURSE]: No. She’s pleasant, a bit confused at times but reorients easily. Nursing home staff are aware and familiar with her baseline.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Got it. Is transport booked?
[WARD NURSE]: Yes, booked for 11:30 AM. All discharge paperwork is complete, including medication summary and nursing home handover form. Please let the team know if there’s any delay or change in her condition.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning. Hi Jane, I’m Sam, the day nurse. I’ll just get handover from Alex, then check in with you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Sam. This is Jane Morgan in bed 4. Jane, could you confirm your full name for us?
[PATIENT]: Jane Morgan.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Jane.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Jane is 24, under Dr Tilney, admitted with acute renal failure. There have been No changes overnight. All observations have remained stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, Any concerns with pain or nausea?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, she’s comfortable and denies nausea.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on the last dose of her IV antibiotics today. The Plan is discharge her home tomorrow, and switching to oral antibiotics.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. And follow-up arranged?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes there's an outpatient appointment with Dr Diani, which has been organized.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Jane, how are you feeling this morning?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay, just keen to go home.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hopefully tomorrow, once we switch you to tablets. I’ll keep an eye on your obs and your last IV antibiotics.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything for Jane from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Alex. Jane, press your call bell if you need anything. I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and your IV.
[PATIENT]: Thank you.
