[PATIENT]: Lawrence Wong, and 25 December 1968.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Any allergies to medications?
[PATIENT]: No, none that I know of.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Overnight he reported a headache so  I gave him some Endone as charted, with good effect, there are no other issues noted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Lawrence, how’s your head feeling now—any pain, nausea, or light sensitivity?
[PATIENT]: It’s okay at the moment—no nausea or light sensitivity.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: we will give you regular analgesia as charted.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes the Panadol is due at 1330. His Obs remain stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. So the plans is we’ll continue regular analgesia, monitor your pain and observations, and let Dr Lee’s team know if anything changes. Lawrence, please buzz if the headache returns or gets worse.
[PATIENT]: Will do. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything else before Jack heads off?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All right, I’m off. Thanks, Lawrence.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Jack. I’ll be back shortly, Lawrence.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His past history includes a coronary artery bypass graft about three months ago. His observations have been stable overnight. He’s still for investigation at this stage.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, all stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Stephen, how are you feeling now?

[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll keep your observations going and wait for Dr. Liu’s team to review and plan the next tests. If you feel more feverish or unwell, press the call bell and let me know.
[PATIENT]: Will do.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Alex. Stephen, I’ll be back shortly to check you over again.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: good Morning, Mr. Keller. I’m Evie, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Jack.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Luke, we’re just doing your bedside handover.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Can you tell us your name?
[PATIENT]: I… I want to go home.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: That’s okay. I’ll just check your ID band… Luke Keller, 74, under Dr. Lee. Thanks.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, Bed 1, Luke Keller, who is 74 years old, under Dr. Lee. Admitted with Alzheimer’s disease. His observations are stable.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s very confused and may become aggressive at times. We need to get security to help us as he punches and kicks at times
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so security know that we will contact them if he gets too aggressive? .
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes. he needs a hosit to transer with  2–3 people as he is heavy. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: how much does he weigh?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s 150 kg and is doubly incontinent of urine and feces and has a pad in situ.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He needs to be fed and must sit fully upright when eating, so he doesn't choke.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His Tablets need to be crushed; he also needs a referral to Speech Pathology.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s a high falls risk.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He needs regular pressure area care and is on a pressure-relieving mattress as he stays in bed most of the time.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How often is he being turned? 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Evry 2 hours Otherwise, he’s stable.

[PATIENT]: Where’s my wife?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll check on that for you, Luke. I’ll be back shortly to help you with breakfast and your morning care.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Is there anything else you need right now, Luke?
[PATIENT]: No… okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Jack. I’ll take it from here.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Gus. I’m Alex, the day nurse. I’ll just get handover from Mia and then we’ll check in with you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Gus, I’m Mia from night shift. Is it okay if we do bedside handover with you?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great, thank you. Could you please confirm your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: Gus Milano, and 12 May 1951.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Gus. And you’re in bed two under Dr. Lee. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, this is Gus, who is 73 years old, admitted today with depression on the background of cancer. He’s just arrived and is still waiting for a psychiatry review, pastoral care, and for Dr. Lee’s team to come by.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so still needs a nursing admission and psych review. How have his observations been?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All stable since arrival QADDS of 1 for HR. He’s tolerating diet and fluids without any issues.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any IV lines or special precautions?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No special supports needed at present. 4 Houry observations.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications all up to date on the chart?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes the Chart’s in the file; the team will write it up when they see him.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Gus, how are you feeling right now—any nausea, pain, or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay physically.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for letting us know. Are you feeling safe here? If you have any thoughts of harming yourself or feel very distressed, please tell us straight away so we can help.
[PATIENT]: I will, thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So the Plan for the morning is to continue routine obs, assist with meals as needed, and we’re awaiting psych, pastoral care, and the medical team review.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep an eye out for those teams and check back after rounds. Anything else outstanding?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mia.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Jess. Bed 4, Sarah Jeffries, 62, under Dr. Lane. Admitted with a head injury after a fall. Sarah’s husband is here at the bedside.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Sarah, could you confirm your full name for me while I check your ID band?
[PATIENT]: Sarah Jeffries.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Jeffries.
[SPOUSE]: Hi.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Overnight she’s been stable with no changes. She’s improving. We’re awaiting discharge planning once she’s fully recovered. Ongoing management of pain with medications and antibiotics, and she’s continuing with physio.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any new concerns overnight—nausea, dizziness, confusion?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, none reported. Still the same and getting better.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Sarah, how’s your pain right now?
[PATIENT]: A bit sore, but manageable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll stay on top of that. I’ll check when your next dose is due. Mark, antibiotics ongoing as charted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, continuing as charted. Physio is ongoing as well.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll touch base with physio about today’s session and with the team about discharge planning.
[SPOUSE]: Do you know when she might go home?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: The team will confirm after they review her and the discharge plan is finalized. We’ll keep you updated today.

[PATIENT]: No, that covers it.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: The Call bell is here within reach. We’ll keep your pain controlled, give antibiotics as prescribed, and coordinate physio and discharge planning. Anything you need before Mark heads off?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sarah. I’ll leave you with Jess.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mark. I’ll be back shortly with your pain meds and an update.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She has a left AV fistula with a good bruit and thrill, and she’s on haemodialysis. She’s booked for dialysis this afternoon and needs the dialysis prescription for this afternoon.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All right, see you tomorrow. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, we’ll see you soon, Mary.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Jerry, I’m Taylor, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just going to get handover from Sam who’s been on the night shift, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Morning, Taylor. This is Jerry Reed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Jerry.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Jerry is 45, under Dr. Harry. He has a history of congestive cardiac failure, IHT, hypertension, type 2 diabetes (diet controlled), and depression.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He came in with bilateral leg oedema. He has a right AV graft and is scheduled for haemodialysis tomorrow afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, he has a right AV graft in situ, and dialysis is tomorrow afternoon.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a 1.2-litre fluid restriction with daily weights. He’s on IV furosemide. We also need lying and standing blood pressures to be done this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll do the blood pressure this afternoon. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for the diabetic educator tomorrow at 1 pm, and there’s a family meeting booked for Thursday at 2:30 pm.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, diabetic educator tomorrow 1300, family meeting Thursday 1430.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Jerry’s been very demanding and at times aggressive with staff. We’ve been using clear communication and de-escalation; please approach with firm boundaries and escalate if safety is a concern.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the heads-up. Jerry, we want to make sure you feel heard and comfortable. If something’s not working for you, let us know and we’ll do our best within the plan we have.
[PATIENT]: Okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any pain or shortness of breath right now?
[PATIENT]: Just the legs feel heavy. No chest pain.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s consistent with earlier. No other acute issues noted on my shift.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll double-check your weight, input/output, and confirm your dialysis booking for tomorrow afternoon. I’ll also set reminders for the orthostatic BPs.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sam. Jerry, I’ll be back shortly with your morning plan and to talk through the fluid restriction and what to expect today.
[PATIENT]: Thanks.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Andrew. I’m Sarah, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Tom, the night nurse—does that sound okay?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Could you tell us your full name, please?
[PATIENT]: Andrew Hamond.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is Andrew Hamond, 81 years old, under Dr. Morris, room 1 bed 2. He came in with sepsis on the background of chronic renal failure secondary to hypertension. He’s on haemodialysis via a right arm AV fistula—thrill is good.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: so no needles in that arm, due to the fistula.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s still on IV antibiotics—vancomycin—and IV therapy. Normal saline is running at 83 mL per hour. He’s due for a vancomycin level tomorrow morning. We’re doing lying and standing blood pressures, daily weights, and strict fluid balance charting.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so Vancomycin is ongoing, a vancomycin  level is due tomorrow morning, he has NS 83 mL/hr.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His next dialysis is on the morning list tomorrow. Blood pressures remain low—systolic 80 to 90—so he’s still on IV fluids. The team plan is to give albumin if his blood pressure doesn’t improve tomorrow after dialysis.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is there another bag of fluids written up after this one goes through? 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, He spiked a temperature last night—38.4°C. We took blood cultures and gave paracetamol with good effect. He’s been afebrile today on my shift and otherwise all his obs are stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll keep an eye out for the culture results and continue monitoring.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Andrew, how are you feeling right now—any fever or chills?
[PATIENT]: No, I feel okay. A bit tired.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks—we’ll keep your fluids going and check your blood pressures lying and standing. Please press the call bell if you feel dizzy or unwell.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Tom. I’ll review the med chart, confirm the vancomycin level time for the morning, and update the fluid balance and weight. Andrew, I’ll be back shortly to do your observations.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Ian. I’m taking over your care from Sam. We’ll do a quick bedside handover if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi both. This is room 1,the patient is Ian Ramsey, 40, under Dr. Morris.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ian, could you confirm your full name for us? do you have any Allergies?
[PATIENT]: Ian Ramsey, only to bees.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ian came in yesterday with severe lower back pain secondary to a urinary obstruction, he has  a long history of kidney problems. He’s still under investigation. The CT showed an obstruction of the ureters and the team are planning to put a stent in. He’s booked for a renal ultrasound on Friday at 2 p.m.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so the plan is for a ureteric stent, and ultrasound Friday  at 1400. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: For pain he’s had Endone as needed and regular Panadol. Observations have been stable and remain unchanged .QADDS of zero.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ian, how’s your pain right now?
[PATIENT]: Still there, but the tablets take the edge off.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. I’ll keep on top of your regulars and let the team know if it ramps up.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything else outstanding?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We will wait for a time for the stent and the ultrasound on Friday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Ian, your call bell is within reach—press if you need anything. I’ll be back shortly to check your obs and pain.
[PATIENT]: Thanks.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Cecilia, I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. Is it okay if we do your handover at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We’re in Bed 1, This is Cecilia Ramos, 38, under Dr Willow. Admitted with a renal obstruction; Her full history is in the notes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll just check your ID band, Cecilia… great, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She had a CT scan last week. She has been charted pain medication. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Cecilia, how’s your pain right now?
[PATIENT]: It’s still there, but manageable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll keep an eye on your timing and make sure you’re comfortable.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The Plan is to discharge at the end of this week and Follow‑up with Dr Willow one week post discharge and book a renal outpatients appointment for two weeks after discharge. The discharge summary is at the front of the notes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  Are we just waiting on medications to go home?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes we are waiting for the discharge meds from pharmacy.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  I’ll chase those up.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s quite anxious. Family is in attendance at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Cecilia, we’ll keep you updated about timing and the medications so you’re not left wondering.
[PATIENT]: I appreciate that. I’ve been a bit worried.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Of course. I’ll check in regularly, and if anything changes with your pain or you have questions, press the call bell.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me. See you tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Anything else you’d like us to know or anything you need right now, Cecilia?
[PATIENT]: No, that’s all. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great—I’ll follow up pharmacy and be back shortly.

[INCOMING_NURSE]:  Good Morning, Nicholas. I’m Mia, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Sam, the night nurse. Is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Nicholas. So, this is Room 3, Bed 1: Nicholas Ferrer, 64, under Dr. Morris. Admitted with painful urination, haematuria, and reported fevers prior to admission.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Nicholas, could you tell us your full name, please, while I check your ID band?
[PATIENT]: Nicholas Ferrer.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you, matches the band. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes diet-controlled, depression, GORD, and gout.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Observations have been stable and he’s afebrile on the ward.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any pain right now, Nicholas?
[PATIENT]: A bit of burning when I go, but otherwise okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We still need to collect a urine MCS, and he is for bloods tomorrow morning as per the request.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, he’s steady.

[PATIENT]: Yep, right here.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.

[INCOMING_NURSE]:Good Morning. I’m taking over now, shall we do bedside handover?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Paulos, this is Maria. She’ll be your nurse today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hello, Mr Gomez Castillo. I’m Maria, your nurse. We’ll talk about your care now—okay?
[PATIENT]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bed 2, This is Paulos Gomez Castillo, 74, under Dr Willow. He came in recently with renal colic—kidney stones—and has a long cardiac history noted in the file.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: He's got a complex cardiac history, I’ll review the notes after handover.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has multiple allergies—documented in the chart—and he’s wearing an allergy band.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I can see the red allergy band—thank you. 
[PATIENT]: Yes.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a soft, cut-up diet. Obs have been stable QADDS of zero.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: BP looks good at 110/80.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s VRE positive so he is on contact precautions.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll make sure the family know how to put on PPE. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s waiting for  a chest X-ray and there is no confirmed time yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep him ready for when they call for him.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on prophylactic Clexane, BD.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is today’s doses charted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, they’re charted.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He is NFR, but still for all regular meds and therapies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Not for resuscitation is the paperwork completed and in the chart?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, it is, He becomes intermittently confused and can be quite agitated at times.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is there anything that triggers him overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No its Mostly in the evening; he needs reorientation and a calm approach helped.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: he’s from a non‑English background but he understands some English. An Interpreter can be arranged if needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Paulos, if you need toilet or water, press the bell—okay?
[PATIENT]: Bell—okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The staff assist when walking, with a forearm support frame.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay We’ll use a gait belt as needed.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has an IDC in situ. Urine is being recorded on the fluid balance chart. His output has been low overnight so will need to be checked hourly. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check the catheter and continue fluid balance documentation.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No IVs currently.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any pain right now, Paulos?
[PATIENT]: Little… okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Small pain—okay, I’ll check your charted analgesia.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the plan for today is to maintain contact precautions; monitor obs; give Clexane BD; soft cut-up diet; staff‑assist mobilising with forearm frame; monitor confusion/agitation and reorient; keep ready for chest X‑ray; continue IDC care and fluid balance.
[PATIENT]: Okay.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything you need now, Paulos?
[PATIENT]: Water… small.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll bring some water and sit you up. Thanks for the handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. Call me if you need anything else before I head off.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Edwin. I’m taking over your care from the night nurse. Is it okay if we do your bedside handover now?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Edwin. So, room 1 bed 3, this is Edwin Palma, 54, under Dr. Willow. Can I just confirm your identity?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Edwin.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has prostate cancer so He has come in for an assessment. He’s had a CT abdomen and an x-ray; both results are still pending.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: When were they done.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: 1000 am this morning. The plan is that he will be discharged if results are negative; otherwise he’ll be treated as an outpatient. We’re still awaiting the team’s review and the go-ahead. Otherwise, he’s stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll keep an eye out for the results and page the team for review once they’re available.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Edwin, how are you feeling right now—any pain or new concerns?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay. No new issues.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great. There are no immediate nursing issues to flag. His Vitals and status stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: All right. Edwin, once the doctors review your scans, we’ll let you know the outcome and next steps. If you’re cleared, we’ll arrange your discharge; if not, we’ll organise the outpatient plan.
[PATIENT]: Sounds good. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Do you need anything before we go?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll hand over the pager to you. Thanks, Edwin.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll be back shortly to update you when we hear from the team.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Ellie. I’m the day nurse coming on my name is Rupert. I’ll just get handover from Sam, who’s finishing night shift. Is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Ellie. This is bed 4, The Patient is Ellie Aline, 23, under Dr. Willow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Ellie—could you tell us your full name, please? 
[PATIENT]: Ellie Aline.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Your name is spelt wrong and I'll confirm your date of birth in the chart.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ellie was admitted for an infection of unknown origin—still under investigation. She has a Background of chronic kidney disease.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s been reporting severe pain; she’s on ongoing pain management. She’s ambulant and self-caring on the ward.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ellie, how’s your pain feeling right now?
[PATIENT]: Still pretty sore, especially when I move.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll review what you’ve had and top up as appropriate.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She hasn’t been seen by the medical team yet today. Ellie is asking about a weekend leave pass if the team agrees.
[PATIENT]: Yes, if it’s safe, I’d like to go out for a few hours over the weekend.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll raise that with Dr. Willow’s team once they review you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Obs-wise, she’s been afebrile on my shift and otherwise stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll recheck your vitals after handover and monitor while we’re investigating the source of infection.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I think that everything is up to date.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the plan is to continue pain management, encourage safe mobilisation, chase the team for review and investigation plan, and discuss the leave pass request with them.
[PATIENT]: Sounds good. Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Anything you need before I head off, Ellie?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay for now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and pain meds.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Renata. I’m taking over your care for the day my name is Fred. Do you mind if we do your bedside handover with Jack?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Renata. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Renata Cola.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. We’re in room 1, bed 5. Renata is 33 years old and under Dr. Willow.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She was admitted with an acute kidney injury of unknown cause.Her Workup is ongoing. She’s still awaiting a renal ultrasound, and she’s booked for a renal biopsy tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Has consent been completed?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Not yet. The consent still needs to be signed. The doctors have already discussed the procedure with her.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll make sure that’s sorted with the team today.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She's For the biopsy tomorrow,and needs to fast from midnight. All the regular medications can be given with sips of water.
[PATIENT]: Okay, she needs to fast from midnight.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s tolerating diet and fluids well for now and is on a strict fluid balance chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep the input/output chart up to date.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She also needs a new cannula today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll arrange a new IV cannula after handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s self-caring and mobilises independently around the ward. No other issues to note at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Renata, do you have any questions or concerns right now?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Just let me know when the ultrasound is.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up on the ultrasound timing and update you. We’ll also remind you this evening about fasting from midnight.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me. I'm off to the shops. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll get started on the cannula and check on the consent and scan time. Press your call bell if you need anything, Renata.
[PATIENT]: Thank you.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Marco. I’m the incoming nurse. I’ll just get bedside handover from my colleague and then we’ll check in with you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Marco. He’s Bed 6 in Room 1, under Dr. Sun. Admitted with nephrolithiasis—kidney stones.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Marco, can you confirm your full name and age?
[PATIENT]: Marco Calasso, 40.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has a background history of depression and asthma. He’s on both oral and IV antibiotics. He’s for a Lithotripsy with Dr. Sun next week.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay what day?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Wednesday, I think. His Main issues overnight have been pain, it has been severe—he’s rating it 10 out of 10 despite regular Panadol, plus PRN Morphine and Endone.
[PATIENT]: It’s been really strong, yeah.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, Marco, we’ll reassess that right after handover.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He still has haematuria. He also had nausea and vomiting; we gave IV metoclopramide with good effect—settled the nausea.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good to hear the antiemetic helped.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]:He has one IV cannula in the right hand— the site is patent and intact.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check the site and flush after handover.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Blood pressure has been elevated; up to 180/86 the team are aware. He’s on FBC and a general diet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: FBC as in fluid balance charting?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—fluid balance charting. General diet otherwise.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  Any other tests or bookings today?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: There may be something pending for tomorrow; waiting on the team to confirm. Lithotripsy is next week.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the plan is to continue oral and IV antibiotics, monitor hematuria and fluid balance, manage pain—consider review since he’s still 10/10—and keep an eye on the BP; team already informed.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Agreed.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Marco, is there anything else worrying you right now?
[PATIENT]: Mostly the pain. The nausea’s better.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. We’ll be back shortly to reassess your pain and give what’s due. Use your call bell if it spikes again.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Marco. I’ll leave you with the day team now.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning. I’ll take over from here—shall we do bedside handover for Bed 3?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Sure. Hi Evan, this is Mia, she’ll be looking after you today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Evan. Can you tell me your name and age?
[PATIENT]: Evan Stephenson, 22.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Evan. We’ll chat while we check a few things.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, Bed 3: Evan Stephenson, 22 years old. He came in after a fall and has rhabdomyolysis with acute kidney failure. He had very low blood pressure in ED and received a Gelofusine infusion stat. He’s more stable now, which is why he’s been transferred to the ward.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s got an IDC in situ, and for strict fluid balance charting. IV fluids are running at 803 mL per hour as charted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Just confirming—eight-zero-three per hour? I’ll double-check the order and the pump after handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, that’s correct per the current order.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on lying and standing blood pressures, daily weights, and daily bloods.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He appears swollen and bruised on the left side of his body. He’s for a review regarding his mobility. At the moment he’s resting in bed and currently stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Evan, any pain right now, or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: Bit sore on the left side, but I’m okay lying still.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll get your pain score shortly and make sure you’re comfortable.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Urine output’s being tracked on the fluid balance?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—IDC is patent and draining, the FBC is up to date.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll check your IV fluids, review the orthostatic BP plan, and keep up with the daily weights and bloods. I’ll also follow up on the mobility review.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. That’s everything from me.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Evan, is there anything you need right now before I check your pumps and observations?
[PATIENT]: Some water if I’m allowed?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll confirm your fluid orders and be right back. Use your call bell if you need anything.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Alex. I’m Priya, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just going to get bedside handover from Sam, the night nurse. Is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Priya. This is Alexander Marek in Room 4, under Dr Gaylor. Alex, can you confirm your full name and date of birth for us?
[PATIENT]: Alexander Marek, 12-09-58.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thank you. Any allergies to medications?
[PATIENT]: None that I know of.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Okay. So, Alex is 66 years old, admitted with acute on chronic renal failure. He’s on home haemodialysis normally.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has a history of end-stage renal failure, type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and depression. He also has atrial fibrillation and is on warfarin.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We need his warfarin level today to guide dosing. ED drew bloods but missed the warfarin/INR, so that still needs to be taken and then please get the doctors to review the result.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll take the INR straight after handover and flag it with the team.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His potassium this morning is 6.2, so very high. The doctors are aware and we’re waiting on their treatment orders. I’ve printed the hyperkalaemia protocol and left it just outside the notes if you need it.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, I see it there. I’ll follow up for orders.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for renal ultrasound and biopsy to be arranged by the renal team.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He's for daily weight and he’s 82 kilograms today.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His Lying and standing blood pressures are stable—no postural drop.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: AV fistula observations are good: there’s a bruit and thrill present.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Blood glucose levels QID; latest BGL is 5.6.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Alex, do you usually dialyze Monday, Wednesday, Friday mornings?
[PATIENT]: Yes, M-W-F in the mornings. I had dialysis yesterday.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I’ve called the dialysis unit to let them know he’s admitted and needs scheduling while he’s here.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, I’ll coordinate with them for the next session.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Otherwise he’s stable at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Alex, anything you want to add or anything you need right now?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll draw your INR now, and chase the team for the hyperkalaemia orders, 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Sounds good. Thanks, Priya.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll get started now, Alex.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Lars. I’m Mia, I’ll be looking after you now. I’m just going to get handover from Sam, the night nurse, at the bedside.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mia. This is Lars Wohler, 42 years old, Room 4, under Dr. Geller.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Lars, we’ll speak about you, and please jump in if you feel up to it.
[PATIENT]: (nods).
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He came in with sepsis with a decreasing level of consciousness, on a background of chronic renal failure stage 4 on peritoneal dialysis. He’s had a full septic workup; results are pending.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Blood cultures sent?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, blood cultures were taken—awaiting results.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s febrile—38.6—and we’ve started IV antibiotics. He’s also on IV fluids at 83 mL per hour.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: The antibiotics are running and fluids 83 mL/hr. Any allergies documented?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: None documented so far; unable to confirm with him given the reduced consciousness.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is he nil by mouth?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—NBM due to decreased level of consciousness.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Analgesia/antipyretics?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s written up for IV paracetamol.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: And code status?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for full resuscitation.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: PD?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His peritoneal dialysis regimen needs review—Dr. Geller will come later to review and advise.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Any other results back yet?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Nothing definitive yet; septic workup pending.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Lars, I’m going to keep you comfortable, we’ll keep your fluids and antibiotics going, and the doctor will be in to see you shortly. If you’re in pain, can you squeeze my hand?
[PATIENT]: (weak hand squeeze)
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. We’ll also keep you NBM until it’s safe.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll check the line site, confirm the antibiotic timing, and chart the IV paracetamol. I’ll also keep an eye on temps and neuro checks, and wait for Dr. Geller’s review and culture results.
[PATIENT]: (nods)
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sam. I’ve got it from here.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Samuel. I’m Mia, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Dan, the night nurse—okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Samuel. We’ll be quick. This is Samuel Edmond in room 4, bed 3.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Samuel, can you confirm your name for me?
[PATIENT]: Samuel Edmond.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks—I’ll just check your wristband for your details. All good.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Samuel is 19 years old, admitted with acute renal failure. He’s been with us a while and is currently awaiting the results of his renal biopsy.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: hopefully they will be back soon.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His Observations have been stable. He’s self-caring and ambulant.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Any restrictions?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No—he can have a leave pass as per Dr. Ross.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any issues overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No issues reported. He’s been comfortable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Samuel, how are you feeling this morning?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good to hear. I’ll keep checking your obs and keep an eye out for those biopsy results. If you plan to head out on leave, just let me know so I can note it.
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Dan. Samuel, buzz if you need anything.
[PATIENT]: Will do.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mindy. This is Alex, the day nurse who’ll be looking after you now. Is it okay if we do your bedside handover?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mindy. I’m Alex. Could you please confirm your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: Mindy Thompson, 16 April 1948.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thank you. And we’re in room 4.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, this is Mindy Thompson, who is 63 years old. She came in about an hour ago with right upper quadrant pain on a background of a liver cyst.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s had an X-ray and a CT done; results are pending.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her observations have been stable since arrival.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The RUQ pain was relieved with morphine with good effect.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s for surgery, but that’s still to be organised pending imaging and surgical review.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her mum is at the bedside in attendance.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her Allergies haven’t been confirmed yet on the chart.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Mindy, how is your pain right now?
[PATIENT]: Much better after the morphine, just a dull ache.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll keep monitoring and can give more as prescribed if you need it. I’ll also follow up your X-ray and CT results and touch base with the surgical team about the plan and timing.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any nausea or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: No.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good. I’ll also confirm your allergy status and ensure you’re comfortable while we wait for the results. If you need anything, press the call bell. Hi there, Mum—thanks for being here.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me. Anything else you’d like to add, Mindy?
[PATIENT]: No, thank you.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll be back shortly with an update once I’ve checked your scans and spoken with the team.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Natalie. I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just going to get bedside handover from Alex, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: That’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Natalie. So, this is room 4, bed 5. Patient is Natalie Caricas, 79 years old, under Dr Ross.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She came in with stomach pain and jaundice. She has a Past history  which includes diabetes and obesity. She’s reporting feeling tired, a bit dizzy, and low in mood.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her urine has been very dark; I’ve sent a urine MCS. She arrived on the ward about three hours ago. Admission obs and paperwork are done, and her observations have been stable since arrival.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Any mobility concerns?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she needs assistance with walking. I’ve flagged that she should be referred to physio.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay so shes an assist with all mobilising and falls precautions in place.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: yes. Diet-wise she’s on a diabetic diet. We’re doing QID BGL monitoring, and she’s on oral hypoglycemics.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: QID BGLs and oral hypos—no insulin charted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No insulin charted at present.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Pain management?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s charted for Endone and morphine PRN for pain. She’s been uncomfortable, so please assess and medicate as needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Will do.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She hasn’t been seen by the medical team yet; she’s here for further investigation. We’re awaiting the team review under Dr Ross.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Natalie, how are you feeling right now—any pain, dizziness, or nausea?
[PATIENT]: My belly still hurts, and I feel a bit light-headed. I’m also just… a bit down.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you for telling us. I’ll check your observations now, get you some pain relief if it’s due, and make sure you’re safe when you get up. We’ll also let the doctors know how you’re feeling when they come.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me: her obs are stable a urine MCS was sent, she's an assist with mobility, and is on adiabetic diet with QID BGLs, oral hypoglycemics, PRN Endone/morphine charted, awaiting team review and physio referral.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Natalie, your call bell is within reach—please ring before you get out of bed and we’ll come and help.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Alex. I’ll take it from here.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Hildy. I'm just here with my colleague to do bedside handover, is that okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi there. This is Hildy Hutter in room 4, bed 6, under Dr. Forbes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hildy, could you tell us your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: Oh… I’m waiting for the bus, dear.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s alright, Hildy. We’ll just check your ID band and IV medications.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hildy is a lovely 91-year-old lady admitted with a urinary tract infection.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s currently on IV antibiotics. The doctors have also charted oral antibiotics to commence tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so the IV ABs running now at 100ml per hour.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes they are Running as charted; the next dose due as per the medication times. I’ve signed the last dose.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s very confused today. Observations have been stable, but she is febrile.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: otherwise she has stable obs but with a temperature. I’ll keep monitoring and encourage fluids as appropriate.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. No other acute issues to flag at the moment.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hildy, you might feel a bit warm—we’re keeping a close eye on you. Are you in any pain right now?
[PATIENT]: I think I should be going home soon… where’s my coat?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll help you with that later. For now you’re safe here. The call bell is right by your hand, and we’ll be popping in regularly.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Plan for the shift: continue IV antibiotics as charted, monitor temperature and observations, and oral antibiotics to start tomorrow. We’ll also keep reorienting and maintain falls precautions given the confusion.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Anything else you need before I head off, Hildy?
[PATIENT]: A cup of tea… maybe.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check what you can have and come right back.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No worries. I’m off. See you both later.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Mary, I’m Alex, I’ll be looking after you today. Is it okay if we do bedside handover?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Could you tell me your full name and date of birth, please?
[PATIENT]: Mary Ocas 21st Feb 2005.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mary. Any medication allergies?
[PATIENT]: No, none.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I'll check your ID number 509127. ok Mary is 20 years old, under Dr Forbes. She came in with severe abdominal pain.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s charted regular paracetamol for pain and I think some other PRN meds. She’s also written up for metoclopramide as an anti-emetic. Bloods and observations were taken but not sure on progress
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s scheduled for a colonoscopy tomorrow, so I guess needs to be nil by mouth from midnight tonight for the procedure. Otherwise, she’s self-caring and ambulant.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mary, how is your pain right now?
[PATIENT]: It’s there, but manageable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll check the timing of your next regular paracetamol. Any nausea?
[PATIENT]: A little earlier, but okay now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: If it returns, we’ve got some medications you can have for that — just use the call bell.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything you need before we go, Mary?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great—press the bell if you need anything. I’ll be back shortly.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Lyndon. I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you now. I’m just going to get handover from Pat, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sam. This is Bed 2, Lyndon Basilakis, who is 50 years old, under Dr. Forbes. He came in with severe abdominal pain and fever.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Lyndon, can you confirm your full name and date of birth for us?
[PATIENT]: Lyndon Basilakis, 12th of March, 1974.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: On my shift he’s been afebrile, but he still reports abdominal pain.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Lyndon, how’s your pain right now, out of 10?
[PATIENT]: About a 6.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I’ve given pain relief with good effect earlier, and he settled, but it does creep back.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Noted. Any nausea or vomiting?
[PATIENT]: A little nausea, no vomiting.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Also, per team request, we need MRSA and VRE surveillance—I've referred/notified the team for that.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Have the surveillance swabs been taken yet?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Not yet we still need to do them.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll follow up and get those done.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other concerns—fluids, IV access, allergies?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No IV access changes to report and no new allergies disclosed to me. Main issue has been the abdominal pain; otherwise afebrile this shift.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Lyndon, I’ll check your observations now, get you something for that pain as due, and I’ll follow up the MRSA/VRE swabs.
[PATIENT]: Thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s all from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Pat. I’ll take it from here.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Benjamin. I'm taking over your care from the night nurse my name is Greg. Is it okay if we do your handover here at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Sure, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Benjamin. So, this is Benjamin Lincoln 51 years old, under Dr T. Lenny. He was admitted with a query acute kidney injury.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His Past history includes diabetes and heartburn. He’s for a renal ultrasound at some point today, and a renal biopsy on Thursday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll keep an eye out for the ultrasound time and make sure you’re ready to go, Benjamin.
[PATIENT]: Sounds good.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was febrile last night, up to 37.6 but he’s been afebrile on my shift. Other observations seem ok.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:And you’ve been up and about?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Didn't really have to get up at night so unsure.
[PATIENT]: I’ve been walking around a bit, yes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Excellent. Any concerns right now—pain, nausea, anything you want us to know about?
[PATIENT]: No, I feel okay at the moment.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Benjamin, I’ll check your obs shortly and keep you updated about the ultrasound time. If you need anything, just press the call bell.
[PATIENT]: Will do, thanks.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, George. I’m Alex, the day nurse. I’m just going to take handover from Maria, who’s been looking after you overnight—okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi George. We’ll keep this brief.In Bed 1 is George Antonio Sanchez, he is 43 years old.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi George. I’ll just check your ID band, infusions and iv cannula. The arm band matches George Antonio Sanchez. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any allergies we should know about?
[PATIENT]: No, none.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: George came in for investigation of high blood pressure. All the tests have been completed; we’re just waiting for the results.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What was his blood Pressure?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: It was a little high I think. If everything comes back within acceptable limits, he’s clear for discharge today as per the team.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. George, how are you feeling right now—any headache, chest pain, dizziness?
[PATIENT]: I feel fine, no symptoms.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He slept all night, and there have been no other issues overnight.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. I’ll keep an eye on the results and update you as soon as they’re in. If all’s good, we’ll get your discharge sorted. How are you going to get home?
[PATIENT]: My son will pick me up. I have to ring him when I am ready to go.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Okay that's good.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Maria. George, press the call bell if you need anything. I’ll be back shortly.

example.text:
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. George Wallace, 78 years old. He was brought in from home following a GP request for review. He has a background of depression and possible early dementia and is now presenting with acute confusion and agitation.
[ED NURSE]: What’s been happening?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Over the past week he’s become increasingly withdrawn, refusing meals, and expressing low mood. His GP prescribed diazepam 5 mg twice daily for agitation, but since then he’s become more confused and restless. Today he was found wandering at home, disoriented. His wife reports he’s barely eaten in two days.
[ED NURSE]: Any observations or assessments done?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Yes, 4AT score is 7. Vitals: BP 134/76, HR 88, Temp 37.4°C, RR 18, SpO₂ 96% RA. He’s alert but disoriented to time and place. No obvious injuries. BGL 6.1.
[ED NURSE]: Current medications?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: On diazepam with last dose last night, sertraline 50 mg mane. No known allergies.
[ED NURSE]:Thanks. Anything else I should know?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: He’s been responding to reorientation during transport when and has settled when we’ve told him his name, the date and time, and that he’s on his way to the hospital. He remains settled but may need constant observations. Oh his wife is the EPOA.
[ED NURSE]: Got it. We’ll continue orientation and arrange close monitoring until the team reviews.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, handing over Mrs. Margaret Lewis, 85 years old, admitted with Alzheimer’s dementia and depression. She’s under Dr. Singh, Geriatrician.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Can you tell me about her current plan?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She has a dementia care plan in place. She becomes anxious during meals and ADLs, but has a positive Behaviour Support Plan documented in her file — strategies include step-by-step prompting, calm tone of voice, and family involvement at mealtimes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s her functional status?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She mobilises with a 4-wheel walker and supervision. Needs full assistance with showering and partial assistance with dressing. She eats better when family are present. They’ve been visiting twice daily, which helps settle her.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Current medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Escitalopram 10 mg, memantine 10 mg. No known allergies. She’s tolerating meds well.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any monitoring or referrals?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on food and fluid charts due to poor intake and has mild weight loss over the past 3 months. Awaiting medical review later today and Psych are planning to see her also. She’s also due for physio input to maintain mobility. Bowels charted — last motion yesterday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Anything else?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Just maintain orientation, continue strategies from her support plan, and liaise with her family who are due at 10AM. Pressure area care completed. All observations stable.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Robert Hughes, 72 years old, currently admitted under a Treatment Authority. Diagnosis is late-onset schizophrenia, admitted with persecutory delusions.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s his presentation today?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He remains suspicious and is refusing meals, stating that his food is poisoned. He has refused his morning risperidone 0.5 mg and is declining all blood tests. He’s also refusing routine obs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any signs of delirium?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes — 4AT score is 6. He appears intermittently disoriented and his mental state is fluctuating. Doctors have requested delirium care strategies — regular reorientation, low-stimulus environment, clear explanations. Food and fluid charts commenced.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s his legal and social situation?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s under guardianship through the Office of the Public Guardian. No local family or supports.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: And the current risk and plan?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s refusing oral meds, so the team is considering alternative routes if refusal persists. Needs close supervision for nutrition, hydration, and risk of further deterioration. Maintain reorientation and escalate if agitation or aggression increases.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll continue with the delirium care approach and monitor intake and risk.
